Review Advances in metal-free carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination: From heteroatom doping to intrinsic defects over the past decade Shuhao Wei Guojun Lan * Yiyang Qiu Di Lin Wei Kong Ying Li * Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou310014, Zhejiang, China Institute of Industrial Catalysis College of Chemical Engineering Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou Zhejiang 310014 China Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou310014, Zhejiang, China * Corresponding author The development of metal-free carbon catalysts has garnered significant attention as a promising approach to address the challenges of sustainable catalysis, particularly in the replacement of toxic and environmentally hazardous mercury-based systems for the coal-based PVC industry. Within a decade of development, the catalytic performance of carbon catalysts has been improved greatly and even shows superiorities over metal catalysts in some cases, which have demonstrated great potential as sustainable alternatives to mercury catalysts. This review provides a comprehensive summary of the recent advancements in carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. It encompasses a wide range of aspects, including the identification of active sites from heteroatom doping to intrinsic carbon defects, the various synthetic strategies employed, the reaction and deactivation mechanisms of carbon catalysts, and the current insights into the key challenges that are encountered on the journey from laboratory research to scalable commercialization within the field of carbon catalysts. The review offers foundational insights and practical guidelines for designing green carbon catalysts systems, not only for acetylene hydrochlorination but also for other heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Graphical Abstract This review provides a comprehensive summary of recent advancements in carbon catalysts used for acetylene hydrochlorination. It covers the identification of active sites, ranging from heteroatom doping to intrinsic carbon defects. Various synthetic strategies employed in the creation of these catalysts are also discussed. Furthermore, the review delves into the reaction and deactivation mechanisms of carbon catalysts. Lastly, it provides current insights into the key challenges faced in scaling up laboratory research for commercialization in carbocatalysis. Keywords Metal-free Carbon catalyst Acetylene hydrochlorination Heteroatom doping Defect engineering 1 Introduction Polyvinyl chloride (PVC), with an annual production exceeding 45 million tons, the third most widely produced polymer globally, is extensively utilized across various sectors, including building and construction, pharmaceuticals, electrical engineering, apparel, and other related industries [ 1,2 ]. It boasts numerous valuable properties, including high resistance to aging and photo-degradation, as well as being non-toxic [ 3 ]. Vinyl chloride monomer (VCM), the precursor to PVC, has been industrially produced since the 1920s through direct acetylene hydrochlorination, using a mercuric chloride catalyst supported on activated carbon [ 2 ]. However, the mercury chloride catalyst, which is toxic and hazardous, has several disadvantages, including the sublimation and loss of the active component due to hot spots (>200 °C) in industrial fixed-bed reactors (C2H2 + HCl → CH2 = CH2Cl, ΔH = −124.8 kJ mol−1), as well as environmental pollution associated with the catalyst manufacture, utilization and disposal. Another established industrial method for producing VCM involves ethylene chlorination/oxychlorination to form ethylene dichloride (EDC), followed by dehydrochlorination of EDC [ 4 ]. While this ethylene-based process has largely replaced acetylene hydrochlorination in oil-rich countries, the one-step acetylene hydrochlorination route remains the primary commercial method in regions with abundant and cost-effective coal resources [ 5 ]. However, under the Minamata Convention on Mercury, adopted by the United Nations Environment Programmer (UNEP), mercury use per unit of production must be reduced by 50% by 2020 compared to 2010. Furthermore, the application of mercuric chloride catalysts in the PVC industry will be prohibited five years after mercury-free catalysts, based on existing processes, become technically and economically viable [ 1,2,6 ]. Consequently, developing an environmentally safe, mercury-free catalyst is imperative to overcome the bottlenecks constraining the growth of the acetylene-based PVC industry [ 7 ]. Since 1975, Kiyonori et al. [ 8 ] reported various metal catalysts including Cu, Hg, Zn, Pd, Ag, Pt, Au, Fe, Co, Ni, Sn, and Bi etc., for acetylene hydrochlorination, more than 20 kinds of metal catalysts have been reported and have been extensively studied for acetylene hydrochlorination. Among numerous mercury-free catalysts, gold supported on carbon has demonstrated the highest activity, leading to systematic and comprehensive studies in recent decades, making it the most promising industrial replacement for mercury-based catalysts [ 9,10 ]. Since 2019, it has been claimed that gold-based catalysts have been successfully applied in pilot-scale applications. However, even after five years, there are still no large-scale applications and a whole-lifetime assessment of gold-based catalysts is still lacking. Despite the significant industrial potential of carbon-based gold catalysts, their high cost and substantial catalyst consumption pose a considerable strain on China’s gold reserves and may lead to financial risks. Additionally, carbon-supported gold catalysts are prone to precious metal loss, sintering, and poisoning under reaction conditions, making them susceptible to deactivation. Carbon-supported ruthenium and platinum have also emerged as viable candidates for non-mercury acetylene hydrochlorination due to their high standard reduction potential and relatively lower cost. However, similar to gold-based catalysts, the high production cost remains a primary factor limiting their further application [ 11–14 ]. Non-noble metal catalysts, such as copper, continue to attract interest for their significantly lower cost, though improvements in activity and selectivity are still required [ 15 ]. Nevertheless, metal-based mercury-free catalysts remain insufficiently optimized, and none have yet achieved full commercialization. Furthermore, a primary limitation of metal-based catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination is their reliance on excess HCl to maintain the metal in its cationic state, preventing reduction and carbon deposition caused by excess acetylene. However, this approach generates substantial waste acid, increasing process complexity and environmental impact. In addressing the bottleneck issues of metal catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination, low-cost carbon materials have emerged as a promising alternative, demonstrating performance comparable to conventional metal catalysts. Carbon materials play a crucial role as support substrates in various industrial catalytic processes, especially under harsh acidic and basic conditions. In addition to serving as supports for metal catalysts, these materials possess remarkable intrinsic properties. Carbon catalysts functions without the need for excess HCl, thereby eliminating waste acid production and streamlining the process. Furthermore, carbon-based metal-free catalysts (carbon catalysts) mitigate issues such as metal loss and product contamination, reducing their environmental impact. Additionally, they offer lower production costs compared to metal-based catalysts. These advantages make carbon catalysts a more sustainable and environmentally friendly solution, with substantial potential to transform the acetylene-based PVC industry. In recent years, carbon catalysts have garnered considerable attention, delivering impressive performance in reactions such as alkane dehydrogenation [ 29 ], and electrochemical transformations [ 30–32 ], and acetylene hydrochlorination [ 6 ]. This positions them at the forefront of heterogeneous catalysis research [ 32,33 ]. Among carbon catalysts, those tailored for acetylene hydrochlorination have received notable interest due to their advantages, including low cost and highly tunable atomic or molecular structures [ 34 ]. The development trajectory of such catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 1(a) . In 2014, Wei et al. [ 17 ] demonstrated that NC nanotubes exhibit promising activity in acetylene hydrochlorination, sparking significant interest in this area. In the same year, Bao et al. [ 7 ] reported a nitrogen-doped graphene-like material (SiC@N-C) on a silicon carbide substrate, which further showcased the potential of carbon catalysts. Operating under an acetylene gas flow rate of 30 h–1 at 200 °C, this catalyst achieved an acetylene conversion rate of 80%, a vinyl chloride selectivity of 98%, and maintained stability with minimal deactivation after a 150-h durability test [ 7 ]. Similarly, Dai et al. [ 16 ] report a non-metallic g-C3N4/AC catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. The g-C3N4/AC catalyst demonstrates notable catalytic performance, although it is slightly lower than that of AuCl3 and HgCl2. Encouraged by these pioneer works, massive attempts have been made to develop advanced N-doped carbon catalysts, targeting the requirements of industrially viable acetylene hydrochlorination catalysts [ 21,35 ]. Researchers embarked on synthesizing a diverse array of nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) catalysts, employing various carbon precursors such as carbon nanotubes [ 17 ], graphene [ 18 ], MOFs [ 36 ], biomass [ 21 ], and polymers [ 37 ]. Employing strategies of heteroatomic modification, these catalysts exhibited notable catalytic activity in acetylene hydrochlorination (Fig. 1(b)). Initially, it was observed that introducing heteroatoms (e.g., B [ 25 ], N [ 38 ], P [ 39 ], S [ 40 ]) into the carbon lattice could significantly enhance catalytic properties. Theoretical studies revealed that the increased electrochemical activity of doped carbon catalysts is attributed to the asymmetric distribution of electronic conjugation within the carbon lattice [ 41,42 ]. Looking forward, it is anticipated that disrupting the electronic conjugation in defective carbon (DC) catalysts could further improve catalytic performance, particularly in intrinsic defect sites, although this remains underexplored [ 43 ]. In 2019, our group demonstrated the feasibility of enhancing catalytic performance through defect engineering, independent of heteroatom doping [ 24 ]. Their findings revealed a direct correlation between the catalytic activity of defective activated carbon and the intrinsic defects on the carbon surface, thereby establishing defect engineering as a viable strategy for enhancing the performance of carbon catalysts. Furthermore, with an advanced understanding of defect structures, our group elevated the activity of carbon catalysts to the level of gold-based catalysts for the first time by employing nano-diamond as a carbon source and precisely regulating the surface defect structure through defect engineering. Collectively, these investigations have propelled carbon catalysts to a level of performance on par with traditional metal catalysts, marking a significant advancement in catalysis research [ 23 ]. To investigate the active sites of metal-free carbon catalysts, our group systematically screened hundreds of carbon materials and evaluated their performance in acetylene hydrochlorination. A volcano-like relationship between acetylene conversion and the sp 3/sp 2 ratio of carbon catalysts was observed, highlighting the critical role of surface defect structures in catalytic performance [ 27 ]. Recent studies have underscored the synergistic effects of heteroatom doping and defects in further enhancing the catalytic efficiency of carbon catalysts [ 44 ]. Our group pioneered the synthesis of a nitrogen-doped porous carbon material enriched with defects, employing PVC as a precursor and leveraging a melamine-assisted crosslinking strategy, which shows excellent catalytic performance in VCM production [ 26 ]. The catalytic performance of the NPCs catalyst was enhanced alongside an increment in carbon defects. Zhu et al. [ 45 ] developed a straightforward strategy to synthesize a carbon material with high nitrogen content and abundant carbon defects. The adsorption capacity of C2H2 and HCl was found to increase with the density of carbon defects and nitrogen content, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. In addition, out group predicted and demonstrated that carbon curvature significantly influences acetylene adsorption and catalytic performance. Notably, the high-curvature defective carbon (HCDC) achieved a 90% acetylene conversion at 220 °C and a GHSV of 300 h–1, far surpassing the benchmark 0.25% Au/AC catalyst we prepared. With a deeper understanding of the active sites, their activity has gradually improved, the catalytic activity of carbon catalysts is no longer the main obstacle to their further industrial application, which strongly demonstrates the potential for commercializing carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination (Fig. 1(b)). Carbon catalysts offer a sustainable alternative for HgCl2/AC catalysts. Their superior activity, stability, and modifiability are derived from tunable surface chemical properties (e.g., acidity, basicity, and electron density) and easy recovery [ 46 ]. As such, carbon catalysts presents a compelling case for replacing conventional catalysts, aligning with the principles of sustainable chemistry. Previous reviews have included some fragmented and preliminary summaries on carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. A comprehensive and systematic review focused specifically on carbon catalysts has yet to be presented. This review aims to address this gap by summarizing recent advancements in carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination, covering aspects from heteroatom doping to intrinsic carbon defects (Fig. 2(a) ). Furthermore, we outline various synthetic strategies for developing carbon catalysts in this field (Fig. 2(b)). Our goal is to provide a concise overview of sustainable carbon catalysts systems for acetylene hydrochlorination while summarizing the current understanding of key aspects of carbon catalysis in this reaction. These include the identification and quantification of active sites, catalytic mechanisms, structure-function relationships, and insights into the challenges encountered in scaling up from laboratory research to commercial applications in the carbon catalysts field. The review offers foundational insights and practical guidelines for designing green carbon catalysts systems, applicable not only to acetylene hydrochlorination but also to other heterogeneous catalytic processes. 2 Recognition of active site from heteroatom doping to intrinsic defects Carbon exhibits various bonding modes, leading to the formation of sp 2 hybrid graphene, sp 3 hybrid diamond, sp-sp2 hybrid graphitic acetylene, and sp-sp 3 hybrid diamond acetylene structures. Additionally, carbon can adopt linear, planar, tetrahedral, and other configurations. This bonding versatility endows carbon materials with a wide range of physical and chemical properties, including conductivity, surface area, porosity, and surface chemistry. These characteristics not only enhance the potential for structural manipulation but also expand their applications across diverse fields [ 47 ]. However, neither pristine graphite nor graphene exhibits significant catalytic activity for alternative acetylene hydrochlorination, requiring modifications to enhance their catalytic properties [ 48 ]. To impart catalytic properties to carbon materials, modification is required, with heteroatom doping and defect engineering being effective strategies. Nitrogen doping has garnered significant research attention due to its ability to modulate electron distribution, creating an electronic environment conducive to efficient acetylene hydrochlorination. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the electron-withdrawing capacity of nitrogen atoms, which generates a net positive charge on adjacent carbon atoms [ 16 ]. Beyond nitrogen, other heteroatoms, including boron, phosphorus, sulfur, and multi-element doping, have demonstrated promising catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination [ 25,39,49 ]. However, the nature of active sites in carbon catalysts remains a topic of debate. Theoretically, it was revealed that the enhanced electrochemical activity of doped carbon catalysts was ascribed to the asymmetric allocation of electronic conjugation structure into the carbon lattice. Prospectively, it is speculated that disrupting the electronic conjugation structure can enhance the catalytic performance of intrinsic defects in carbon materials. Recently, the role of intrinsic structural defects in the catalytic properties of carbon materials has gained increasing attention. Notably, studies have revealed that calcining N-doped carbon materials to remove nitrogen dopants can result in higher catalytic activity compared to their pristine-doped counterparts. Both heteroatom doping and defect site introduction are considered potential active centers. This section will discuss recent advancements in acetylene hydrochlorination catalysts, focusing on single heteroatom-doped carbons, dual-doped carbons, and carbon materials with intrinsic defects. 2.1 Single heteroatom doped carbon catalysts Heteroatom doping is employed to modify the bulk and surface properties of carbon materials, optimizing their performance for specific applications. The heteroatom is covalently and uniformly integrated into the carbon matrix, disrupting the sp² carbon network. This integration introduces defects, bends graphitic planes, increases interlayer spacing, and/or creates uneven charge distributions within the framework [ 50 ]. These structural changes are widely regarded as determinants of active sites across various applications [ 51 ]. In a simplified model, a highly electronegative heteroatom, such as nitrogen (N), withdraws electrons from adjacent carbon atoms, imparting them with a partial positive charge. The extent of this positive charge depends on the strength of the heteroatom’s pull on the electron cloud surrounding the carbons. Conversely, a heteroatom with lower electronegativity, such as boron (B), donates electron density to adjacent carbons, rendering them partially negatively charged. This uneven electron distribution creates distinct active sites within the carbon framework, modifies the overall electronic band structure, and facilitates interactions with nucleophiles or electrophiles [ 52 ]. A clear example is seen in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction on N- and B-doped carbon materials, where nitrogen and boron doping exhibit opposite effects on charge transfer between adsorbed C2H2 and the catalyst [ 53 ]. In boron-doped carbon nanotubes, charge flows toward acetylene, while in nitrogen-doped nanotubes, it flows away, allowing for tunable charge states of the acetylene molecule through appropriate dopants. Unlike boron and nitrogen, sulfur (S) has an electronegativity similar to carbon, resulting in minimal charge redistribution within carbon planes under this simplified model. However, sulfur has a larger atomic size strongly impacts the doping effect. Introducing larger heteroatoms distorts the carbon lattice, expands graphitic spacing, and introduces defects and strain within the structure. These structural defects disrupt the symmetry of charge (or spin) density distribution, localizing electrons at specific sites and creating active sites [ 54 ]. Furthermore, the increased interlayer spacing enhances intercalation potential, making these structural parameters essential for acetylene hydrochlorination. Li et al. [ 40 ] find that a strong coupling with significant overlap between the projected electronic density of states (PDOS) of the S p orbitals and the acetylene π orbitals, suggests a robust interaction. 2.1.1 Nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts Nitrogen (N), positioned adjacent to carbon (C) in the periodic table, readily forms stable covalent bonds with carbon, making it the most extensively studied heteroatom in carbon materials over the past decade. This interest stems from nitrogen’s abundance, ease of incorporation, and the distinctive properties and enhanced performance of N-doped carbons. With an atomic size close to that of carbon, nitrogen forms C–N bonds (1.41 Å) nearly identical in length to C–C bonds (1.42 Å), thereby minimizing structural distortion and preserving the carbon network geometry [ 55 ]. Due to its higher electronegativity relative to carbon, nitrogen generally increases electron density in the surrounding structure, affecting the electronic properties of the carbon framework. Depending on its bonding configuration, nitrogen can exist in forms such as pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic, as well as other types like oxidized, quaternary, or vacancy-associated nitrogen [ 54 ]. Recently, substantial efforts have been devoted to developing advanced carbon catalysts to meet the demands of industrially viable acetylene hydrochlorination.[ 56 ] While significant progress has been achieved with NC catalysts, their activity remains lower than that of metal or mercury-based catalysts, and their stability requires further enhancement [ 57 ]. Additionally, producing NC materials with well-defined and controllable nitrogen species is challenging, leading to ongoing debate regarding the catalytic mechanism of NCs in acetylene hydrochlorination [ 58 ]. Many studies have confirmed that nitrogen doping improves the catalytic activity of carbon in acetylene hydrochlorination, yet the precise relationship between specific nitrogen species and reaction activity remains unclear. Wei et al. [ 17 ] found a linear relationship between acetylene hydrochlorination activity and graphite-type nitrogen, identifying quaternary nitrogen as the most efficient species in N-doped carbon nanotubes. In contrast, Dai et al. [ 59 ] reported that pyrrolic nitrogen plays the primary role in enhancing activity in carbon catalysts, ranking nitrogen types as pyrrolic N > graphitic N > pyridinic N in terms of catalytic contribution. Li et al. [ 60 ]. identified pyridinic nitrogen as the active site in N-doped porous carbon derived from ZIF-8, while Bao et al. [ 5,7 ] concluded that the catalytic activity originates from carbon atoms bonded to pyrrolic nitrogen. Their findings also suggest that acetylene adsorption on quaternary and pyridinic nitrogen sites is minimal due to the endothermic nature of the adsorption process. Pyridinic N is sp 2 hybridized, bonded to two carbon atoms at the edges of hexagonal carbon units, and contributes one π-electron to the π-system. Its lone pair occupies an sp 2 orbital, remaining outside the delocalized π-system and forming an edge termination. This configuration imparts high basicity and strong electron-donating properties to pyridinic N [ 61 ]. Electronegatively, pyridinic N is negatively polarized, while adjacent carbon atoms are positively charged, shifting the valence band to more positive values. In acetylene hydrochlorination, the electrophilic addition of HCl to acetylene is primarily governed by the electron affinity of the active site. N-doping enables precise tuning of carbon’s electron affinity, mimicking the behavior of active metal cations and allowing N-doped carbon to function as a metal-free catalyst. Specifically, pyridinic N enhances the basicity of the carbon framework, promoting HCl adsorption and acetylene activation, which makes it highly effective as a solid base catalyst. Dai et al. [ 16 ] proposed that HCl is adsorbed on the nitrogen atom, while acetylene adsorbs on the carbon atom in g-C3N4. The rate-limiting step is the proton transfer from nitrogen to the chloroethenyl group (Figs. 3(a) , (b)). This dual activation of reactants, combined with efficient product desorption, results in g-C3N4/AC showing higher catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination than AC. Specifically, g-C3N4/AC catalyst with a 7.39% nitrogen content achieved a 76.52% acetylene conversion at 50 h–1 GHSV and 180 °C, compared to 45.24% with AC under identical conditions. Li and colleagues [ 62 ] developed a carbon-based metal-free catalyst enriched with pyridinic N species. Characterization and density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that catalytic activity originates from three active pyridinic N sites in a stepped configuration. Notably, a pyridinic N site near a hydrogen atom exhibited higher activity due to the H-Cl interaction, stabilizing the transition state and lowering the energy barrier. The energy barriers at these sites are 29.8 and 47.4 kcal mol−1, substantially lower than the 83.2 and 84.4 kcal mol−1 observed elsewhere. Although the catalytic properties of NC materials are well-studied, these materials usually contain multiple nitrogen species. Thus, synthesizing carbon catalysts with a single nitrogen configuration is both intriguing and valuable for isolating the specific effects of N doping. A pure pyridine-based organic polymer with only one nitrogen species was successfully designed, exhibiting high catalytic activity with an acetylene conversion of 88% and vinyl chloride selectivity over 99%. Experimental and DFT studies confirmed that the pyridinic N atom in the pyridine ring serves as the active site, with acetylene insertion into HCl likely being the rate-determining step [ 58 ]. Additionally, a green poly(o-phenylenediamine) framework with a phenazine backbone and defined pyridinic N species was synthesized as an ideal model for studying the catalytic role of pyridinic N in acetylene hydrochlorination [ 37 ]. Experimental results demonstrated a correlation between the pyridinic N content in the samples and their acetylene conversion rates (Fig. 3(c)). As an important application, this polymer was subsequently used as a precursor for preparing an N-doped carbon catalyst, which displayed acetylene hydrochlorination activity comparable to that of a 6 wt% Hg/C catalyst. Pyrrolic N and pyridinic N share similar physical and chemical properties. Pyrrolic N is also sp 2 hybridized, typically bonded to two carbon atoms and one hydrogen atom. Its lone pair electrons partially participate in π-system conjugation, resulting in limited electron delocalization and minimal impact on the conductivity of carbon materials, unlike pyridinic N. Structurally, pyrrolic N exhibits slight electronegativity, inducing a mild positive charge on adjacent carbon atoms. It is also less basic than pyridinic N, as its lone pair electrons are more dispersed and less available for proton interactions. Similar to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N contributes alkalinity to the carbon matrix, promoting HCl adsorption and acetylene activation. For instance, Bao et al. [ 7 ] developed a nitrogen-doped graphene-like material on a silicon carbide surface (SiC@N-C), exhibiting notable acetylene hydrochlorination properties. Under an acetylene gas flow rate of 30 h–1 at 200 °C, this catalyst achieved 80% acetylene conversion with 98% selectivity for vinyl chloride and demonstrated slow deactivation over a 150-h lifespan. The activity increased consistently with the number of accessible pyrrolic N sites, regardless of precursor or N-doping method, confirming that carbon atoms bonded to pyrrolic nitrogen serve as active sites (Fig. 3(d)). TPD results indicated that the acetylene adsorption capacity of the pyrrolic N site was significantly higher than that of pyridinic N, supporting pyrrolic N as the active site. DFT calculations further elucidated the roles of pyrrolic N in the reaction mechanism. The results show that acetylene does not readily adsorb on quaternary or pyridinic N sites due to the endothermic nature of the adsorption process (Figs. 2(e), (f)). Furthermore, the projected density of states revealed that both pyrrolic and pyridinic N introduce localized electronic states below the Fermi level at carbon sites, unlike quaternary N, and the pyrrolic N generating a higher energy level and density, enhancing adsorption further (Fig. 2(g)). Additionally, Lin et al. [ 63 ] identified pyrrolic-N content and electrical conductivity as key catalytic descriptors for N-doped carbons, emphasizing that their interplay must be carefully managed to maximize catalytic activity. They also believe that strong adsorption of reactants alone does not fully determine catalytic performance; excessively strong adsorption can negatively impact reaction energetics and hinder overall efficiency. Furthermore, Chen et al. [ 56 ] demonstrated that moderate HCl adsorption on pyrrolic nitrogen stabilizes the transition state, lowering the energy barrier, whereas strong HCl adsorption on pyridinic nitrogen destabilizes the transition state. Quaternary N replaces carbon atoms within hexagonal rings, adopting sp 2 hybridization and bonding with three neighboring carbon atoms. Unlike pyridinic N and pyrrolic N, quaternary N has a distinct electronic structure [ 46,64 ]. Additionally, the positive charge on N polarizes adjacent carbon atoms negatively through coulomb screening, shifting the energy levels of the carbon material to more negative values [ 65 ]. Generally, the electrophilic addition of HCl to acetylene is highly dependent on the electron affinity of the active site. If the electron affinity of carbon can be as well tuned as the active metal cation by doping, then it is expected that the doped carbon may serve as a carbon catalyst for hydrochlorination. Based on this consideration, Wei et al. [ 17 ] explored the idea of acetylene hydrochlorination on NC nanotubes (N-CNTs). N-CNTs are found to be active as one novel heterogeneous catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, possessing good activity (TOF = 2.3×10–3 s–1) and high selectivity (>98%) and good linearity between the quaternary nitrogen content and conversion is revealed (Figs. 3(h), (i)). They found that the nitrogen doping enhanced the formation of the covalent bond between C2H2 and N-CNT compared with the undoped CNT, which is due to interactions between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of NCNT and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of C2H2, and therefore promoted the addition reaction of the C2H2 and HCl into C2H3Cl. 2.1.2 Boron-doped carbon catalysts The boron (B) atom, with an outer electron configuration of 2s 2 2p 1, is a second-row element like nitrogen, but its electronic structure differs significantly. Boron has only three valence electrons, forming three covalent bonds, resulting in a total of six electrons and making it electron-deficient, thus “seeking” two additional electrons to achieve stability in a four-coordinate bond with Lewis bases. When doped into carbon materials, boron most stably adopts an in-plane configuration, known as in-plane doping [ 66 ]. In this configuration, boron maintains the sp 2 hybridization of the carbon lattice, typically in the form of BC3, allowing integration into the π system. This unique structure has garnered interest regarding the catalytic activity of boron-doped carbon materials in acetylene hydrochlorination. Li et al. [ 25 ] developed B-doped carbon nanodots (B-CNDs) with an inhomogeneous distribution of local electrostatic potential, exhibiting excellent catalytic performance and high durability in acetylene hydrochlorination. The acetylene conversion reached over 98% at 220 °C and an acetylene gas hourly space velocity of 30 h–1. Notably, compared to the pristine graphene (p-G), all B-doped carbon surfaces displayed uneven electrostatic potentials, suggesting that doping leads to an uneven surface atomic charge distribution (Fig. 4(a) ). This increased charge inhomogeneity likely creates electronic structure defects, enhancing surface adsorption and activation of substrates due to the electrostatic potential differences and improved polarization. The inhomogeneous electrostatic potential distribution in B-CNDs enhances surface adsorption and activation of substrates relative to pure carbon surfaces. Fig. 4(b) shows the calculated elementary steps for the acetylene hydrochlorination process. Under conditions where C2H2 binds more strongly than HCl, the reaction initiates with C2H2 adsorption. On a pure carbon surface, C2H2 interacts with an electroneutral C atom, whereas B incorporation forms a -BC₃ structure within the carbon plane. Subsequent insertion and adsorption of HCl on B sites with similar adsorption energy (~-70 kJ mol−1) activates C2H2 on -BC₃ sites, coordinating with HCl to form VCM with a minimum energy barrier of 23.47 kJ mol−1 across five surfaces. This indicates that -BC₃ sites are active sites. The formation of VCM is the rate-determining step. Experimental results showed that the -BC₃ active sites demonstrated superior catalytic performance, aligning qualitatively with computational models. To further thoroughly investigate the effect of dopants on the adsorption of C2H2 and HCl, Li et al. [ 67,69 ] have investigated ten different adsorption sites on carbon nanotubes. As shown in Figs. 4(c), (d), the pyridine configuration with three nitrogen/boron is readily bonded with carbons in acetylene which has the largest binding energy among various adsorption sites. Moreover, the contrasting electronegativities of B and N atoms lead to distinct modifications when doped into carbon materials [ 67–69 ], and the electron transfer behaviors between each atom and C2H2 were found to be opposite [ 53 ]. The charges flow to or away from acetylene respectively on boron and nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (Fig. 4(e)). 2.1.3 Sulfur-doped carbon catalysts The sulfur (S) atom (χ = 2.58) has an electronegativity similar to that of carbon (χ = 2.55), indicating that the covalent bond between S and C atoms is essentially non-polarized [ 70 ]. However, the C−S bond length is 1.78 Å, approximately 25% longer than the C−C bond, leading to a structural mismatch. This mismatch favors the form of five-membered ring structures (e.g., thiophene and thiazole). In other cases, it can also bend the sp 2 planar configuration of graphene, distorting the aromatic system to some extent. Additionally, sulfur doping in carbon materials introduces an orbital mismatch between sulfur and carbon atoms, creating an uneven spin density distribution, which may impact catalytic performance [ 71 ]. Zhang et al. [ 72 ] explored the effect of sulfur-doped carbon materials on acetylene hydrochlorination. The S-doped carbon catalyst demonstrated favorable catalytic activity, achieving 47% acetylene conversion under reaction conditions of GHSV of 90 h–1 at 180 °C, outperforming pristine carbon materials. The spin density plays a critical role in determining catalytic active sites. Sulfur doping alters the charge density and partially disrupts the chemical inertia of the carbon carrier, enhancing electron transfer between the carrier surface and reactants (Figs. 5(a) –(d)). Furthermore, the spin density significant changes at the C atoms adjacent to S atoms, compared to the undoped model, which effectively enhances HCl adsorption, leading to excellent catalytic activity. Li et al. [ 40 ] employed nano-digging technology to fabricate a series of porous carbon-supported sulfur (S) moiety catalysts. The optimized SC-600 catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance in the hydrochlorination of acetylene to vinyl VCM, achieving a high space-time yield (STY) of 23.74 kgvcm kgs –1 h–1 and maintaining stability for over 300 h. Sulfur quantum dots (S-QDs) provided a significant advantage in adsorbing and activating C2H2 and HCl, contributing to SC-600’s superior catalytic performance (Figs. 5(e), (f)). DFT calculations further explored the catalytic mechanism of the S-QD sites, revealing that carbon atoms surrounding the S-QDs exhibit strong electronic coupling, with significant electron transfer from the S-QDs to adjacent carbon atoms. This transfer creates an electron-deficient ring around the S-QDs, rendering them positively charged, while the coordinated carbon atoms acquire a negative charge, forming a charge-polarized site similar to a frustrated Lewis acid-base pair. Electron-deficient sites, such as high-valence metal sites, effectively adsorb and activate electron-rich acetylene molecules, while charge-polarized sites are adept at adsorbing and dissociating polarized molecules like HCl. Thus, the synergistic interaction between S-QDs and coordinated carbon atoms provides an ideal structural environment for the adsorption and activation of C2H2 and HCl. Fig. 5(g) illustrates the interaction between S p orbitals and acetylene π orbitals, showing strong coupling, while charge density difference analysis (Fig. 5(h)) highlights significant adsorption of acetylene by S-QDs. The complete reaction pathway for acetylene hydrochlorination catalyzed by S-QDs is shown in Fig. 5(i). Initially, acetylene adsorbs directly above the S-S atom pair, where it is activated by the S-QDs through p-π coupling to form the C2H2 intermediate. Subsequently, a gas-phase HCl molecule adsorbs onto an edge sulfur atom at the S-QD-carbon matrix interface, with H and Cl atoms oriented toward the S and C atoms, respectively, forming a non-standard hydrogen bond. The activated C2H2 and HCl molecules then undergo a one-step addition reaction to form VCM, following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, with an energy barrier of 0.94 eV. 2.2 Dual heteroatom doped carbon catalysts The presence of different heteroatoms may cause the formation of defects, and hence of uneven charge distribution on the synthesized carbon catalysts, which would possess unique and catalytically beneficial physical and chemical properties. Co-doping involves doping of two different heteroatoms into the carbon network, which could bring structural synergy. 2.2.1 Boron and nitrogen co-doped carbon catalysts Boron, nitrogen, and carbon atoms share similar sizes, and the incorporation of boron or nitrogen atoms into carbon materials effectively mitigates structural distortion within the carbon network [ 73 ]. Due to the contrasting electronic properties of boron and nitrogen atoms, co-doping these elements into carbon materials induces significant electronic effects, particularly enhancing HCl adsorption. The interaction between pyridinic N and B enables the otherwise inactive pyrrolic N atom to contribute to HCl adsorption. Dai and coworkers synthesized a boron- and nitrogen-co-doped oxide graphene catalyst, observing that HCl binding strength followed the order: oxide graphene < N-doped oxide graphene < B,N-co-doped oxide graphene (Figs. 6(a) , (b)). The B,N-co-doped catalyst achieved nearly 95% acetylene conversion, significantly outperforming singly B or N-doped graphene, and approaching the performance of Au and Hg catalysts [ 18 ]. DFT provided insight into acetylene adsorption, revealing that while B-doping alone has limited effect, various N species interact differently with HCl. In N-doped graphene (N-G), a two-coordinated pyridinic N at the cluster edge displayed strong HCl adsorption, while pyrrolic N showed minimal adsorption, consistent with previous findings. In B, N-co-doped graphene (B, N-G), higher adsorption energies were observed across all N species, enhancing the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. B incorporation transitions pyrrolic N from an “inactive” to an “active” state, significantly increasing catalytic activity. However, for graphitic N at the graphene center, HCl adsorption was minimal, showing no significant interaction with B. The synergistic effect of B and N also impacts catalyst stability. Wei et al. [ 57 ] found that boric acid modification altered the electronic structure of PAN-derived carbon, creating a boron-nitrogen co-doped mesoporous carbon (B, N-MC) catalyst with exceptional stability in acetylene hydrochlorination. B, N-MC catalysts effectively suppress carbon deposition, enhancing stability. 2.2.2 Sulfur and nitrogen co-doped carbon catalysts In acetylene hydrochlorination, acetylene donates an electron to the active site of NC catalysts. Sulfur often synergizes with nitrogen in carbon materials, enhancing performance for various applications [ 74 ]. Li and coworkers [ 20 ] found that sulfur doping effectively increases the pyridinic N content in N-doped carbon materials. The S, N co-doped carbon catalyst demonstrated higher acetylene conversion compared to N-doped carbon, as the specific C atom adjacent to pyridinic N becomes more likely to adsorb reductive C2H2 with the aid of the sulfide group. DFT calculations were conducted to further explore the role of S in the co-doped catalyst. In pyridinic N structures, charge density difference contour plots reveal a noticeable increase in charge density from the C atom (between N and S) toward the N atom after sulfur introduction. This observation is supported by changes in calculated Bader charges: the Bader charge of N atoms decreases from –0.79 to –0.99 e, while the charge increases from 1.22 to 1.37 e for C atoms. These results indicate that the specific C atom adjacent to pyridinic N readily adsorbs C2H2 with the support of the sulfide group, favoring the catalytic process (Figs. 6(c)–(f)). In contrast, for pyrrolic N structures, no significant change in charge density between the C and N atoms occurs upon sulfur introduction, and the Bader charges of both atoms decrease, suggesting that the sulfide group does not enhance catalytic activity in pyrrolic N structures. This finding indirectly supports the conclusion that C atoms adjacent to pyridinic N are active sites for acetylene hydrochlorination. Zhu and coworkers [ 49 ] demonstrated that varying sulfur content affects pyrrolic N levels in catalysts and confirmed a synergistic effect between sulfur and nitrogen for acetylene hydrochlorination. The S,N co-doped carbon catalyst exhibited enhanced C2H2 adsorption. 2.2.3 Phosphorus and nitrogen co-doped carbon catalysts Phosphorus and nitrogen can be homogeneously incorporated into a carbon lattice, altering its chemical properties and then regulating its acetylene hydrochlorination properties [ 75 ]. Li and coworkers [ 39 ] developed a novel, highly active nitrogen- and phosphorus-co-doped carbon catalyst, prepared using 1-ethylsulfonate-3-methylimidazolium dihydrogen phosphate ([ESO3HMim⁺H2PO4]) as a phosphorus source and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium dicyanamide ([EMim⁺N(CN)2]) as a nitrogen source. This catalyst demonstrated unexpectedly high acetylene hydrochlorination activity, with a space-time yield comparable to that of advanced Au-based catalysts. Phosphorus atoms bonded with nitrogen in pyridine structures were identified as the active sites for the top-performing NP-C600 catalyst. Acetylene can simultaneously coordinate with both N and P atoms, releasing significantly more energy than at other active sites (Figs. 6(g), (h)). The reaction pathway of acetylene hydrochlorination on ortho-position NP was mapped out (Fig. 6(i)). The first step involves acetylene adsorption and activation on the active site, forming intermediate Ims1 through the transition state TS1. HCl then coordinates with Ims1, with the H atom bonding to a C atom of C2H2 to form TS2. Subsequently, the H–Cl bond breaks, and the Cl atom shifts to another C atom of C2H2, forming intermediate Ims2, followed by desorption to yield the final product. Computational analysis across various sites confirmed that acetylene hydrochlorination most likely occurs at the ortho-position NP following the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. 2.3 Carbon materials with carbon defects Heteroatom-doped carbon materials exhibit remarkable properties due to heteroatoms modifying the local π-electron density [ 76,77 ]. Recent studies have further revealed that the catalytic activity of undoped carbon nanomaterials can be significantly enhanced by strategically managing intrinsic carbon defects within the framework [ 78–80 ]. According to the second law of thermodynamics, defect-free crystalline materials are nonexistent, a principle that also applies to carbon nanomaterials. The presence of intrinsic carbon defects inevitably affects the overall charge distribution within the carbon matrix, increasing the density of potential active sites and enhancing the catalytic performance of carbon nanomaterials [ 80–82 ]. As understanding of carbon defects deepens, it has become clear that intrinsic defect structures within the carbon skeleton significantly influence catalytic performance [ 83,84 ]. Historically, defect studies have focused on the effects of carbon’s porous structure on material and charge transfer, leaving the structure-activity relationship between defect structures and catalytic performance largely unexamined. Today, advanced characterization techniques, such as Spherical Aberration Transmission Electron Microscopy, provide a clearer view of various defect structures. Additionally, developments in computational chemistry allow for detailed analysis of local electronic structures at specific defect sites, elucidating reaction pathways and adsorption/desorption behaviors at each elementary reaction step [ 43 ]. Defect structures in carbon catalysts include edge structures, hole sites, topological defects, doped metal or non-metal atoms, and binding sites among these features. These defects alter the local electronic structure of carbon materials, creating potential active sites for catalytic reactions [ 82,85,86 ]. 2.3.1 Intrinsic carbon defects Early studies on carbon catalysts focused primarily on physicochemical properties and the roles of various heteroatoms or metal species, often overlooking the function of intrinsic carbon defects [ 79 ]. A key question remains: do intrinsic defects contribute to catalytic performance? Extrinsic defects can be minimized by controlling synthesis conditions and processes, but intrinsic defects are unavoidable. Thus, a comprehensive understanding of the electronic structure and catalytic mechanisms of intrinsic carbon defects is essential for advancing research in more complex carbon-based systems. Intrinsic defects can modify the surface properties and electronic structure of carbon substrates, enhancing the adsorption capacity for C2H2 and HCl, thereby influencing their catalytic performance. The intrinsic defects on the carbon surface or edges can serve as highly active sites for acetylene hydrochlorination [ 23 ]. Our group has demonstrated that high-temperature treatment (900 °C) promotes surface graphitization of nanodiamonds, forming a nanodiamond core surrounded by a graphitic shell rich in defects (ND@G) [ 23 ]. The raw nanodiamond (ND) consists of a crystalline diamond core and an amorphous carbon shell decorated with oxygen-containing groups (Fig. 7(a) ), which are effectively removed by dehydration and cross-linking at 900 °C. The absence of these groups and lattice reconstruction likely generates numerous defects (Figs. 7(b), (c)). These engineered defects in nanodiamond-graphene composites achieve a breakthrough in enhancing the catalytic performance of carbon catalysts. Under reaction conditions of 220 °C and 300 h–1, an impressive acetylene conversion rate of 50% was attained, along with exceptional vinyl chloride selectivity of 99.5%, nearly equivalent to the catalytic activity of 0.25% AuCl3/AC under identical conditions. Notably, ND@G is the first carbon catalysts to demonstrate performance comparable to that of 0.25% Au/C (Figs. 7(d), (e)). This study highlights the potential for commercializing carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination and provides valuable insights for designing high-performance carbon catalysts for heterogeneous catalysis. However, the production cost of nanodiamonds is extremely high, surpassing that of gold-based catalysts, making the industrial application of the ND@G catalyst theoretically feasible but practically challenging. Among all carbon materials, activated carbons (ACs) are the only ones widely applied in industry due to their low cost and ease of large-scale production. ACs are polycrystalline materials with crystallite sizes of 2–5 nm, consisting of sp 2-hybridized graphitic structures. While they lack the long-range order of graphite and have unclear connections between graphite fragments, their structure is well-suited for practical applications [ 24 ]. The surface defects of ACs are more abundant than that of the crystallized carbon materials such as CNTs, graphite, or graphene [ 87,88 ]. To explore the industrial application potential of ACs in acetylene hydrochlorination, Li et al. [ 24 ] conducted extensive research on AC systems. To create defective structures on the AC surface, a metal nitrate (Mg(NO3)2 or KNO3) assisted method was employed. The catalytic performance of defect-rich activated carbon (D-AC) is greatly improved compared with AC after imported defect structure. Notably, the acetylene conversion rate of the catalyst increases with higher defect content, suggesting that defect sites may serve as the active sites of carbon catalysts (Fig. 8(a) ). Edges are the most common intrinsic defects in carbon frameworks, as perfect crystals cannot exist without boundaries. Due to differences in bonding states between edge sites and basal planes, edges exhibit distinct electrochemical and thermodynamic properties. In typical hexagonal graphitic networks, edge sites are classified as zigzag or armchair edges [ 43,89 ]. To investigate the role of defective sites on carbon catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination, Li et al. [ 24 ] utilized density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the adsorption energy differences of reactants at various defect sites compared to pristine graphene. Binding energies for C2H2 and HCl were found to be –0.62 and –0.18 eV at zigzag edges, and –0.35 and –0.13 eV at armchair edges, respectively. In comparison, the binding energies on pristine graphene were –0.29 and –0.19 eV. These stronger binding energies at defect sites help stabilize reactants on the catalyst’s active centers. The reaction pathway at both defective and pristine sites was further analyzed, as shown in Fig. 8(b). This pathway involves five steps: C2H2 adsorption (A), HCl insertion (B), HCl activation (C), and product formation/desorption (D, E, F). The energy barriers for transition states TS1 and TS2 on zigzag and armchair edges were calculated to be 1.40 and 0.90 eV, and 1.38 and 0.83 eV, respectively. For pristine graphene, these barriers were 1.41 and 1.37 eV, indicating that products desorb more readily from defect sites than from pristine sites. This comparison of reactant binding and reaction pathway barriers highlights the enhanced reactivity associated with defect sites. Although defect engineering has been identified as an efficient method to adjust the reactivity of carbon catalysts in various chemical reactions, it is still difficult to quantitatively characterize the carbon materials with specific kinds of active sites and defect sites. In consequence, it remains a great challenge to find a parameter to quantitatively define the intrinsic defective sites of carbon catalysts. Li et al. [ 24 ] have conducted a comprehensive examination of carbon catalysts across various systems, revealing the utility of the sp 2:sp 3 hybridization structure as a quantitative metric for evaluating the catalytic efficacy of carbon catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. Li et al. [ 24 ] first studied the catalytic performance and sp 2:sp 3 hybridization structure of graphite-oriented series carbon catalysts. The relationship between the reaction rate and sp 3% content is given in Fig. 8(c). It is interesting to see that a volcanic-like curve relationship between the catalytic performance and the sp 3% content appears. The optimum sp 3% content for sp 2-generated carbon catalysts is 32%. Furthermore, given the structural complexities of the various sp 2-oriented carbons, the ND material (sp 3-oriented carbon) was chosen as a model catalyst to understand the effect of the sp 2:sp 3 hybridization ratio from another perspective. The relationship between the reaction rate and sp 2% content is given in Fig. 8(d). Interestingly, a similar volcanic curve between the sp 2 content and the reaction rate is observed, and the optimum sp 2 content for sp 3-oriented carbon is also around 34%. This important result proposes a direct relationship between the surface hybrid structure and the activity in acetylene hydrochlorination, which is promising to build a general design principle of carbon catalysts. The theoretical models in DFT calculations were employed based on the ND materials with various sp 2:sp 3 ratios, including graphene and diamond for comparison (Figs. 8(e), (f)). The binding energies of C2H2 and HCl are -1.73 and -0.32 eV, –1.64 and –0.44 eV, –1.71 and –0.26 eV, and –0.56 and 0.27 eV, respectively, for sp 2:sp 3 (hybridization ratio of the diamond (111) surface) = 0.08, 0.25, 0.50 and 0.75. The corresponding values for graphene and diamond are 1.10 and –0.27 eV, and –0.16 and –0.30 eV, respectively. From the calculations, it is indicated that the sp 3 and sp 2 hybridized structure materials have much stronger binding energy than pure graphene and diamond. The suitable binding energy for the sp 2 and sp 3 compound materials is beneficial to stabilizing the reactants on the active center on the catalysts. Besides, the local electronic redistributions make the charge densities of the sp 2 and sp 3 structures quite different in the ND-oriented carbons. Bader charge analysis shows that the C2H2 molecules on the substrate with sp 2:sp 3 of 0.75 have less charge than those on the substrate with sp 2:sp 3 of 0.08, which favors the homolytic cleavage of the C–H bonds. As a result, there is a very weak interaction between the C2H2 molecule and substrate (sp 2:sp 3 = 0.75), which is unbeneficial for the subsequent reactions. These results reveal that the composite structure of sp 2 and sp 3 possess better catalytic activity in acetylene hydrochlorination than simple sp 2 (graphene) or sp 3 (nano-diamond) carbon materials, and the relationship between the sp 2:sp 3 ratio and catalytic activity is a volcanic curve. 2.3.2 Carbon defects strengthened by heteroatoms In essence, both heteroatom doping and defect structure regulation serve to modulate the local electronic structure of carbon materials, altering the adsorption/desorption dynamics of reactants, reducing the reaction energy barrier, and catalyzing the catalytic reaction [ 85,90 ]. While the contribution of intrinsic defect structures and heteroatom doping in carbon materials to catalytic reactions has been subject to debate, numerous studies have unequivocally demonstrated their collective role in enhancing the catalytic performance of carbon catalysts. In light of this, integrating defect structures into heteroatom-doped carbon materials may further augment their catalytic performance [ 43 ]. To understand the “synergistic effect,” it is crucial to examine both the similarities and differences between the catalytic mechanisms of intrinsic defects and heteroatom dopants. Heteroatom doping is one of the most extensively studied methods for enhancing the catalytic activity of carbon-based nanomaterials [ 43 ]. From a defect chemistry perspective, heteroatom incorporation introduces extrinsic 0D point defects within the carbon lattice, as atoms with varying electronegativities replace carbon in the sp 2-hybridized network. This substitution optimizes the local electronic structure by redistributing spin or charge density and reducing the HOMO-LUMO energy gap. Moreover, these positively charged sites catalyze stepwise reactions through rapid electron transfer, as dopants improve the material’s conductivity. As a result, the neighboring carbon atoms activated by heteroatom doping act as the actual active sites, rather than the heteroatoms themselves, thereby enhancing overall catalytic performance [ 79 ]. The action principles of heteroatoms and intrinsic carbon defects on carbon framework are quite similar. Both of them can effectively affect the electronic structure of localized carbon sites, modify the adsorption/desorption behavior of reactive species, lower the reaction energy barrier, and thus reduce the required overpotential for acetylene hydrochlorination. The optimized carbon sites are normally regarded as the potential active sites. Given the similar mechanism, heteroatoms are always introduced into the intrinsic defect-rich carbon materials to achieve the optimization of catalytic performance [ 6 ]. Definitely, the intrinsic defects cannot be separated from heteroatom-doped carbon materials, thus the exploration of the combined action of these two factors is extremely essential. To investigate the synergistic effect between doped heteroatoms and defects, Zhu et al. [ 22 ] prepared a nitrogen-rich DC catalyst by adjusting the carbonization temperature to control both the heteroatom doping level and the defect structure. The carbon defects in NC were systematically controlled by removing N atoms at varying temperatures (Fig. 9(a) ). The catalytic performance of the synthesized NC for acetylene hydrochlorination improved with increasing carbon defect density (Figs. 9(a), (b)). Further studies reveal that the defect structures in NC catalysts significantly enhance the adsorption of C2H2 and HCl, thereby effectively facilitating their conversion (Figs. 9(c), (d)). This phenomenon is further supported by the DFT results. The most stable adsorption structures are shown in Figs. 9(e), (f). In these catalysts, nitrogen atoms serve as adsorption sites for HCl, while carbon atoms adsorb C2H2. The adsorption energies (E ads) of HCl and C2H2 on PG-N were calculated to be −3.24 and −4.61 kcal mol−1, respectively. In comparison, DVG-N exhibited significantly enhanced adsorption: the E ads of C2H2 on DVG-N1 and DVG-N2 were −6.45 and −5.89 kcal mol−1, while the Eads of HCl were −5.55 and −5.07 kcal mol−1, respectively. These findings demonstrate that the presence of carbon defects significantly strengthens the adsorption of HCl and C2H2, facilitating the catalytic reaction. Additionally, previous studies consistently show a positive correlation between defect density and catalytic performance, indicating that increasing defect content enhances the activity of heteroatom-doped carbon catalysts. Li et al. developed a simple one-step method to synthesize a fragmentary g-C₃N₄ framework with a porous structure and abundant nitrogen defects, using melamine formaldehyde (MF) resin as an oxygen-containing precursor. The oxygen species in MF resin act as oxidants, inducing partial decomposition of the g-C3N4 framework, resulting in a porous structure and nitrogen defects. These defects significantly enhance the catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination. DFT calculations reveal that HCl preferentially adsorbs onto N2c atoms at zigzag edges of the g-C3N4 framework, while acetylene adsorbs via π-bond interactions between C2H2 and carbon atoms bonded to N2c. Notably, F-g-C3N4 exhibits stronger adsorption of both acetylene and HCl compared to P-g-C3N4, with both frameworks (especially F-g-C3N4) favoring HCl adsorption over acetylene (Fig. 9(g)). The reaction energy profiles for acetylene hydrochlorination on F-g-C3N4-N1 and P-g-C3N4 are depicted in Fig. 9(h). The reaction initiates with HCl adsorption, where the H atom bonds to the N1 site. Acetylene then co-adsorbs, forming an intermediate system. In the Ts4 step, the activated H–Cl bond breaks, activating acetylene. The Im5 step involves the formation of a C–Cl bond, producing the CHCl=CH⁻ intermediate. In the Ts6 step, the H–N1 bond breaks, and CHCl=CH⁻ detaches from F-g-C3N4-N1 or P-g-C3N4. This step, identified as the rate-determining step, is followed by the final desorption of VCM. The energy barriers for F-g-C3N4-N1 (38.1 kcal mol–1) and P-g-C₃N₄ (62.0 kcal mol–1) indicate that acetylene hydrochlorination proceeds more readily on the fragmentary g-C3N4 framework. These findings underscore the pivotal role of nitrogen defects in enhancing the efficiency of acetylene hydrochlorination. Similarly, Zhu and Wei et al developed a simple strategy to synthesize a carbon material with high nitrogen and rich carbon defects. Both of them find that the catalytic performance of the N-doped carbon material enhanced alongside an increment in carbon defects. There is a good synergistic effect between doped heteroatoms and defects. 2.3.3 Intrinsic carbon defects strengthened by curved structure Recently, materials with highly curved surfaces are beneficial for the adsorption and activation of small molecules due to the tensile strain effect and local electric field enhancement and have been employed in plenty of emerging research fields, such as catalysis, adsorption, pharmaceutical compound containers, and batteries [ 93 ]. Bao et al. [ 93 ] found that under the optimal adsorption configuration, the adsorption of small molecules such as H2 and CO on the concave surface of the carbon layer is stronger than that on the convex surface of the carbon layer [ 94 ]. Furthermore, the H2 adsorption energies are enhanced with increased curvatures. Jia et al. [ 95 ] found that constructing curvature structures of carbon catalysts can improve their electrochemical performances. However, compared with other applications, the investigations on the contribution of highly curved structured catalysts into acetylene hydrochlorination systems are still in their early stage, and their potential strengths in boosting the overall catalytic performance also deserve further emphasis and interpretation To elucidate the impact of the curvature of the catalysts on the intrinsic activities, our group delved into the underlying mechanisms governing the catalytic prowess conferred by the defective curvature structure employing theoretical calculations. The adsorption energy of HCl remains relatively consistent across both curved and flat surfaces, while the curvature significantly impacts the adsorption energy of C2H2 (Figs. 10(a) , (b)). Specifically, the out-curved surface demonstrates a substantial enrichment effect on C2H2 adsorption. The reaction proceeds through the C2H2 or HCl adsorption (A), co-adsorption of HCl or C2H2 (B), the transition state of C-Cl bond formation accompanied by the HCl activation (C), and VCM formation and desorption (D,E) (Fig. 10(c)). Theoretical insights unveiled that the Curvature-out model exhibited superior binding energy towards acetylene and hydrogen chloride molecules compared to the Plane model. Furthermore, the Curvature-out model demonstrated the lowest acetylene hydrochlorination energy barrier, indicative of its capacity to enhance reactant adsorption, diminish the reaction energy barrier, and promote the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. This work demonstrates that acetylene hydrochlorination can more readily occur on out-curved surfaces than on flat and in-curved surfaces, which guides designing high-performance metal-free carbon catalysts for heterogeneous catalytic processes. To further investigate the impact of curvature structure on the catalytic efficacy of acetylene hydrochlorination, our group synthesized a high-curvature defective carbon (HCDC) characterized by defective curvature architecture. The curvature structure was confirmed through transmission electron microscopy (TEM), the diameter of the mesoporous of HCDC catalysts is about 7 nm, and the framework of HCDC is composed of multiple layers of graphite domain (Fig. 10(d)). Remarkably, the acetylene conversion rate attained by the HCDC catalyst reached 90.2% under reaction conditions of 220 °C and acetylene gas space velocity of 300 h–1, which is significantly better than that of the DC catalyst without curvature structure (Fig. 10(e)). Furthermore, the acetylene conversion of HCDC is significantly surpassing the performance of the benchmark 0.25% Au/AC catalyst. Additionally, through comparative analysis of the acetylene adsorption capacities of catalysts per unit surface area, it was discerned that the HCDC catalyst, characterized by a specific curvature structure, boasted a 98-fold higher acetylene adsorption capacity compared to the DC catalyst devoid of curvature structure (Fig. 10(f)). Furthermore, kinetic studies have demonstrated that the curvature structure possesses strong adsorption for C2H2 molecules, which is consistent with the TPD-MS results (Figs. 10(g)–(h)). This proof-of-concept study reveals the fundamental mechanisms driving the superior performance of carbon catalysts with curved nanostructures and presents a straightforward, environmentally friendly method for large-scale production of carbon materials with precisely controlled nanostructures. 2.4 The comparison of various carbon catalysts Heteroatom doping and defect engineering have gained significant attention due to their favorable effects on conversion, selectivity, and stability (Table 1 ). Catalytic performance often varies with structural differences among catalysts. For instance, both HCDC and PAN-400-air-N2 are nitrogen-doped catalysts derived from PAN, but their catalytic performances differ substantially. PAN-400-air-N2 achieves 93% acetylene conversion at 280 °C with a GHSV of 50 h–1, while HCDC maintains 90% acetylene conversion under more stringent conditions of 220 °C and a GHSV of 300 h–1. Different types of carbon catalysts, such as heteroatom-doped, defect carbon, and defect-rich doped carbon catalysts, demonstrate varying performances in acetylene hydrogenation reactions. Heteroatom-doped catalysts generally offer good catalytic performance but may exhibit lower catalytic activity compared to defect-based catalysts. Moreover, doping control is challenging, cost-intensive, and prone to carbon deposition. Nitrogen-doped catalysts exhibit a strong affinity for acetylene and typically show excellent acetylene conversion. However, excessive acetylene adsorption can promote acetylene self-polymerization, leading to catalyst deactivation. The coke deposition gradually increased with the increasing amount of nitrogen in the materials [ 57,96 ]. In contrast, boron-doped carbon materials, which exhibit opposite chemical properties to nitrogen, also demonstrate excellent catalytic activity. Recent research indicates that incorporating boron into NC catalysts reduces catalytic activity but enhances stability [ 57 ]. While single doping (e.g., B, N, S, P) can improve catalytic activity to some extent, its effect is often limited and may not be sufficient to ensure long-term catalytic stability. Multi-doping (e.g., co-doping of N, B, S, P) enhances catalyst performance significantly through synergistic effects among the dopants, improving both activity and stability. Defect carbon catalysts provide abundant active sites through defects, leading to enhanced catalytic activity. However, excessive defects may destabilize the catalyst structure, and precise control of the defect structure is difficult. Defect-rich doped carbon catalysts, combining the advantages of heteroatom doping and defects, exhibit superior catalytic performance, selectivity, and stability. However, they are challenging to synthesize, expensive, and may face performance instability. Notably, our recent findings suggest that incorporating specific curvature structures into nitrogen-doped defect carbon catalysts can further improve their catalytic efficiency. 3 Synthetic strategies for carbon catalysts Regulating the doping levels and defect structures of metal-free carbon catalysts is crucial for enhancing their catalytic performance. By employing various synthesis strategies, the distribution of heteroatoms, doping concentrations, and defect types can be precisely controlled to optimize the catalyst’s electronic structure, active site density, and interactions with reactants. For instance, the choice of precursors, such as nitrogen-containing organic molecules or metal-organic frameworks, significantly influences the doping efficiency and type of heteroatoms introduced. Additionally, controlling heat treatment temperatures and atmospheres (e.g., inert or oxidative environments) allows for tailored defect formation and heteroatom embedding. Techniques such as acid washing, plasma treatment, or surface modification further refine the catalyst’s microstructure and surface chemistry. These strategies enable the molecular- or atomic-level design of high-performance carbon catalysts. In summary, the rational design and precise regulation of heteroatom doping and defect structures in carbon-based nonmetallic catalysts, guided by diverse synthesis strategies, can fundamentally enhance their overall performance, addressing the multifaceted demands of heterogeneous catalysis. 3.1 Synthetic strategies for heteroatom doping carbon catalysts Heteroatom-doped porous carbons can be synthesized through two primary approaches: post-synthetic treatment of preformed porous carbons with heteroatom-containing precursors, or pyrolysis of heteroatom-rich precursors [ 55 ]. The post-synthetic method typically results in heteroatom deposition on the carbon surface, whereas pyrolysis enables the uniform incorporation of heteroatoms throughout the entire porous carbon matrix. In some cases, these methods are combined to maximize heteroatom loading. Each approach produces porous carbons with distinct advantages and specific limitations. This section provides a systematic overview of the various synthetic strategies for carbon catalysts employed in acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.1.1 Post synthesis of heteroatom doping carbon catalysts 3.1.1.1 Nitrogen doping by NH3 To overcome the inherent limitations of unmodified carbon, functionalizing carbon through successive reactions with nitrogen-containing reagents is a widely adopted strategy to enhance catalytic performance. Among various nitrogen sources, NH3 is the most commonly used reagent for introducing nitrogen into porous carbons. At elevated temperatures, NH3 decomposes into reactive species such as NH2, NH, and atomic nitrogen and hydrogen. These radicals etch carbon fragments to increase porosity and replace oxygen-containing groups on the carbon surface, forming nitrogen functional groups like pyridinic, pyrrolic, and quaternary nitrogen [ 120–123 ]. Bao et al. demonstrated that reacting SiC with CCl4 at high temperatures produces small graphene flakes on the SiC surface. N element can be in-situ doped into the lattice of carbon by high-temperature thermal treatment under the atmosphere of NH3, to form a NC material. By adjusting parameters such as the NH3/CCl4 ratio, temperature, and reaction time, the textural structure and chemical composition of the carbon layer can be finely tuned while preserving the macro-morphology of the SiC granules (Fig. 11(a) ). The resulting silicon carbide-derived carbon nanocomposite (SiC@N-C) exhibited a core-shell morphology with a nitrogen content of 7.1% (Figs. 11(b), (c)) and achieved an acetylene conversion rate of 80% at 200 °C, atmospheric pressure, and a space velocity of 30 h–1. Similarly, Li et al. [ 119 ] used high-temperature NH3 treatment to prepare a nitrogen-doped, high surface area mesoporous carbon for the direct conversion of acetylene to vinyl chloride. Their catalyst demonstrated high catalytic activity, achieving 77% acetylene conversion and over 98% vinyl chloride selectivity at 200 °C and a space velocity of 1.0 mL min–1 g–1. Furthermore, the catalyst maintained stable performance over 100 hours of testing without significant deactivation. 3.1.1.2 Nitrogen doping by other nitrogen sources Given the potentially similar functionalities of NH3, various amines, including urea, melamine, dicyandiamide, and nitrates have also been investigated as nitrogen sources. Among these, urea and melamine have been the most extensively studied due to their low cost and effectiveness in achieving relatively high nitrogen doping levels, reaching up to approximately 20 wt% [ 124,125 ]. Utilizing nitrogen-containing compounds as nitrogen sources is an effective strategy to enhance the catalytic performance of commercial activated carbon (AC). The preparation process for nitrogen-doped activated carbon catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 11(d). This method involves impregnating activated carbon with a nitrogen-containing precursor through an impregnation process, followed by carbonization under an inert atmosphere. Dai et al. [ 16 ] conducted extensive research on the preparation of heteroatom-modified activated carbon materials. Using dicyandiamide and melamine as nitrogen sources, combined with the impregnation method, they effectively enhanced the hydrochlorination performance of commercial AC. Theoretical calculations suggested that nitrogen doping increased the catalyst’s adsorption energy for HCl, likely contributing to the observed improvement in catalytic performance. Additionally, Dai et al. [ 59 ] explored polyaniline (PANI) as a nitrogen source, producing a high-performance nitrogen-doped catalyst that exhibited significantly enhanced catalytic activity and stability. Similarly, Li et al. [ 118 ] prepared a nitrogen-modified activated carbon catalyst using urea as the nitrogen source. Their findings demonstrated a substantial increase in acetylene adsorption due to N incorporation. Lu et al. [ 44 ] utilized green, low-cost carrageenan in combination with urea to synthesize a nitrogen-modified carbon material. The nitrogen modification yielded a high nitrogen content, uniformly dispersed within the carbon matrix. Moreover, optimizing the annealing temperature further enhanced the catalyst’s acetylene adsorption and catalytic performance. In addition to the usual nitrogen sources, Han et al. [ 38 ] explored the use of coconut shell activated carbon (CAC) to adsorb neutral red (NR), a representative dye in printing and dyeing wastewater, for preparing a NC catalyst. This metal-free catalyst demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination. The optimal 3NR/4CAC catalyst achieved a C2H2 conversion rate of 97.9% and maintained stability over a 200-h lifetime test. Catalytic analysis identified pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen as the active sites for acetylene hydrochlorination, with pyridinic nitrogen being the most active due to its lowest reaction energy barrier, while quaternary nitrogen exhibited no catalytic activity. To investigate the mechanism of pyridinic nitrogen formation, Reactive Force Field (ReaxFF) molecular dynamics simulations were performed. As shown in Fig. 11(e), NR molecules adsorbed onto the amorphous carbon surface, where amino nitrogen atoms gradually dehydrogenated and bonded with carbon atoms in the support. The amino nitrogen then detached from the NR molecule, forming a pyridinic nitrogen precursor. Over time, nitrogen was doped into the carbon structure, leading to the formation of pyridinic nitrogen, which plays a key role in catalytic performance. 3.1.2 Direct synthesis heteroatom doping carbon catalysts Compared to post-treatment methods, which involve multiple synthetic steps, direct synthesis offers a more convenient, one-step approach for preparing NC. This method typically follows one of two strategies: Direct carbonization of nitrogen-rich precursors, such as molecules with cross-linkable groups (e.g., –CN, –NH2), nitrogen-rich polymers, ionic liquids, or biomass derivatives [ 126,127 ]. Direct carbonization of carbon precursors mixed with nitrogen dopants, including amines like melamine, urea, and aniline compounds commonly used in post-treatment methods as well. Both strategies allow for the homogeneous incorporation of nitrogen functionalities throughout the carbon framework, resulting in more stable nitrogen sites compared to surface doping achieved through post-synthetic methods. This leads to materials with improved structural uniformity and stability, essential for catalytic applications [ 128,129 ]. 3.1.2.1 Ionic liquids derived heteroatom doping carbon catalysts Ionic liquids hold great promise in the research and synthesis of carbon materials. As precursors, they offer exceptional design flexibility and functionality for carbon materials due to their tunable chemical composition, high thermal stability, and environmentally friendly properties. Moreover, ionic liquids enable self-doping during the synthesis process, optimizing the electronic structure of carbon materials and facilitating the development of high-performance heteroatom-doped catalysts. Li et al. [ 39 ] synthesized and characterized a novel N, P-co-doped carbon-based catalyst using nitrile- and phosphorus-functionalized ILs (Fig. 12(a) ). Task-specific ionic liquids (ILs) enable the uniform incorporation of heteroatoms throughout the carbon matrix, ensuring consistent distribution. Furthermore, modified IL precursors facilitate the simultaneous introduction of multiple heteroatoms, creating defects that induce uneven charge distribution within the carbon structure. These defect-rich structures impart unique physical and chemical properties that are highly advantageous for catalytic applications. The NP-C600 catalyst achieved a space-time yield (STY) of 1.81 gvcm gcat –1 h–1 at 210 °C, which is higher than other reported carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination (Fig. 12(b)). Experimental and theoretical studies confirmed that the superior performance of the catalyst is attributed to its nitrogen and phosphorus coordination structure. This breakthrough in IL-derived, heteroatom-doped carbon materials represents a significant advancement in the development of efficient metal-free catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. Li et al. [ 130 ] synthesized NC materials with diverse nitrogen configurations by carbonizing a binary ionic liquid (IL) mixture of [EMIM][N(CN)2] and [EMIM][NTf2] at varying temperatures Their study investigated the dynamic reaction pathways of NC catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. Upon activation, the reaction follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, with pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen acting as dual active sites. However, pyridinic nitrogen is deactivated first due to strong hydrogen chloride adsorption, leading the reaction to proceed via the Eley-Rideal mechanism with pyrrolic nitrogen as the sole active site (Fig. 12(c)). This work provides a novel perspective on the catalytic behavior of NC catalysts. Additionally, Li and colleagues [ 25 ] developed a boron-rich carbon catalyst by utilizing a boron-containing ionic liquid precursor to synthesize boron-doped carbon nanodots (B-CNDs). The IL-derived B-CND catalyst exhibited high catalytic performance (Figs. 12(e)–(h)), achieving a space-time yield (STY) of 1.19 gvcm h–1 gcat –1. This performance is comparable to state-of-the-art metal-free catalysts and surpasses that of many Au- and Pd-based catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.1.2.2 Biomass and organic waste-derived heteroatom doping carbon catalysts In the preparation of heteroatom-doped carbon materials, it is essential to optimize both the synthesis complexity and the cost of precursors. Compared to ionic liquids, biomass provides a readily available and easily processed source for heteroatom-doped carbon materials [ 131,132 ]. Various renewable biomass sources hold considerable potential for enhancing catalyst performance.
