However, traditional methods for producing NC materials often involve complex synthesis processes, external nitrogen sources, or non-renewable carbon and nitrogen precursors. Therefore, there is a critical need to develop scalable methods for synthesizing highly efficient NC catalysts via simple, green, and cost-effective approaches. Carbon materials derived from starch have attracted significant attention due to their high surface area, tunable surface chemistry, and controllable electrical conductivity. Starch is a sustainable, renewable, and environmentally friendly resource that can easily form composites in particulate or monolithic forms [ 133,134 ]. Natural wheat flour, for instance, contains approximately 10%–12% gluten and 13%–20% fats, vitamins, and minerals, many of which are nitrogen-rich. Globally, around 700 million tons of wheat are produced annually, with gluten being a major by-product of the wheat industry [ 135 ]. Due to gluten-related health concerns, gluten is often removed, making wheat flour and gluten-abundant, low-cost nitrogen sources for producing N-doped carbons for catalytic applications, such as acetylene hydrochlorination. Our group synthesized an N-doped mesoporous carbon extrudate with a high concentration of quaternary nitrogen species by directly carbonizing wheat flour and gluten with silica [ 21 ]. This approach is a low-cost, scalable method (Figs. 13(a) –(c)). The resulting metal-free carbon extrudate catalyst demonstrated excellent performance in vinyl chloride monomer production via acetylene hydrochlorination, achieving 48.5% acetylene conversion and over 99% vinyl chloride selectivity at 220 °C, along with outstanding stability. Summarily, Shen et al. [ 112 ] developed a green, efficient, and low-cost nitrogen-doped soybean meal carbon (SBMC) catalyst through simple carbonization of soybean meal (SBM) in the presence of zinc chloride. Thanks to SBM’s high inherent nitrogen content, no additional nitrogen source is required. During synthesis, ZnCl2 acts as both a dehydrating agent and a pore-forming additive, facilitating the formation of a porous structure. The SBMC catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination, achieving an initial acetylene conversion of over 99% and a vinyl chloride selectivity of 98% at 200 °C within the 110-h operational period. Carbon-containing by-products, as well as industrial and domestic waste, offer abundant and cost-effective precursors for producing NC materials [ 33,136 ]. Transforming living waste into valuable carbon resources is of great importance for environmental protection. Jin et al. synthesized a NC catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination using waste cigarette butts as a precursor via a simple ammonization process. The resulting CB-derived NC catalyst exhibited a high specific surface area, a large nitrogen doping content, a defective structure, and strong C2H2 adsorption ability. These features enabled the N-CB-800 catalyst to achieve an acetylene conversion of 71.8% at 220 °C and a space velocity of 100 h–1. Shell-based biomass materials, with their wrinkled surfaces and pore-rich structures, also offer high specific surface areas that enhance adsorption and catalytic performance [ 103 ]. Additionally, the natural nitrogen content in walnut shells provides abundant active catalytic sites in the biochar. Wu et al. [ 103 ] developed a nitrogen-doped biochar catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination using natural walnut shells as the starting material, with dicyandiamide or dicyandiamide-formaldehyde condensation products serving as nitrogen sources (Figs. 13(d)–(f)). The 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic activity, achieving a C2H2 conversion of 94.5% at 220 °C and a space velocity of 45 h–1, attributed to the high content of quaternary nitrogen as active sites. The addition of formaldehyde effectively inhibited carbon deposition during the reaction, enhancing the thermal stability of the metal-free nitrogen-doped biochar catalyst. Furthermore, Xu et al. [ 102 ] utilized a simple calcination process to convert chitosan into NC catalysts (labeled as Chi800 catalysts). The resulting Chi800 catalyst exhibited 5.88% total nitrogen content, comprising pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen species. Pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen active sites enabled Chi800 to achieve an acetylene conversion of 91% at 220 °C. To enhance catalyst stability, ZnCl2 was employed as a pore-expanding agent, yielding the Chi800-E catalyst with a specific surface area of 1299 m2 g–1. Chi800-E demonstrated an acetylene conversion of 94% and maintained good stability over a 60-h test at 220 °C. Similarly, Lu et al. [ 100 ] developed a series of carbon and nitrogen-doped materials using D(+)-glucosamine hydrochloride (D-GH), an inexpensive biomass precursor with high nitrogen content. By regulating the nitrogen content through direct pyrolysis, they synthesized the D-GH-800 catalyst, which achieved a nitrogen content of 6.28% and an acetylene conversion of up to 99%. The catalytic activity of D-GH-800 was closely linked to the density of pyridinic nitrogen content. To address catalyst deactivation caused by carbon accumulation, a novel regeneration strategy using ZnCl2 activation was proposed to remove carbon deposits from the pores of the deactivated catalyst. This regeneration process successfully restored the activity of D-GH-800 and extended its operational lifetime. 3.1.2.3 MOF-derived N-doped carbon materials Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely utilized as precursors for synthesizing porous carbon materials, with applications in catalysis, gas storage, and electrochemical capacitance [ 137,138 ]. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) stand out due to their exceptional thermal and chemical stability, making them ideal precursors for producing NC materials in situ. ZIF-derived carbons have been synthesized in diverse morphologies, including 3D nanoporous structures, core-shell architectures, and rod-like forms. Furthermore, the introduction of a secondary nitrogen source into ZIFs enables precise tuning of the pore structure and nitrogen content [ 139,140 ]. The development of MOF-derived nitrogen-doped porous carbon and its application in acetylene hydrochlorination represents a promising and exciting area of research. Li et al. [ 36 ] synthesized bamboo-shaped carbon nanotube (B-CNT)-modified spherical activated carbon (SAC) by carbonizing ZIF-8/SAC composites at high temperatures, with ZIF-8 grown in situ on the SAC surface (Fig. 14(a) ). This process resulted in the formation of highly dispersed nanoparticles averaging 10.5 nm in size, along with bamboo-shaped carbon nanotubes (B-CNTs) measuring 40–80 nm in diameter on the SAC surface (Figs. 14(b), (c)). The modified SAC exhibited excellent catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination, achieving an acetylene conversion rate of 81% and a VCM selectivity of over 99%. The enhanced performance is attributed to the highly dispersed ZIF-8-derived nanoparticles, which provide abundant active sites with easy access to hydrogen chloride and acetylene, facilitating efficient acetylene hydrochlorination. Additionally, the B-CNTs improved the porosity of the material, effectively inhibiting coke deposition. The optimized 17% ZIF-8/SAC catalyst not only enhanced the adsorption of reactants but also reduced product adsorption, minimizing coke formation and further improving the catalyst’s efficiency and stability. Furthermore, Li et al. [ 96 ] also utilized ZIF-8 as a precursor to synthesize ZIF-derived porous carbon materials, incorporating melamine as an additive to optimize the nitrogen content. By optimizing the mass ratio of ZIF-8 to melamine, Li et al. [ 96 ] developed various catalysts and found that catalytic performance depended not only on nitrogen content but also on the physical structure of the catalyst. The optimal catalyst, featuring a high specific surface area and suitable pore diameter, achieved an acetylene conversion of 60%, with only a slight decline in activity over 50 h. The addition of melamine endowed the Z4M1 complex with a unique morphology and favorable pore structure while also adjusting the relative ratios of three nitrogen species within the NC [ 96 ]. Similarly, Chao et al. [ 60 ] reported a high-activity, stable N-doped carbon catalyst derived from ZIF-8. Their catalyst, calcined at 1000 °C, demonstrated a high acetylene conversion of approximately 92% and maintained excellent stability over a 200-h test at 220 °C and a space velocity of 30 h–1. 3.1.2.4 Polymer-derived N-doped carbon materials High-temperature carbonization typically results in the complete decomposition of most organic matter, limiting the range of suitable precursors for carbon material synthesis [ 141 ]. While ionic liquids, with their unique molecular structures, have attracted significant research interest as carbon precursors, their high cost and low carbon yield hinder their widespread application. Synthesizing well-defined carbon materials from cost-effective precursors remains a critical challenge. Commercial activated carbon, primarily derived from biomass, is economically viable, but the inherent structural and chemical heterogeneity of biomass-derived carbon restricts its use in catalytic applications. Therefore, selecting optimal carbon precursors is essential for designing carbon catalysts with specific functionalities [ 48 ]. Unlike ionic liquids and biomass, polymers offer distinct advantages as carbon precursors, including lower cost, well-defined molecular structures, controllable chemical compositions, and established processing methods. These properties enable polymer architectures to be preserved during carbonization, allowing precise control over the composition and structure of the carbon catalysts at the molecular level. Starting with polymers of well-defined structures facilitates targeted functionalization and fine-tuning of catalyst properties [ 142 ]. Despite decades of research into alternative carbon precursors, polymers remain the preferred choice for developing carbon catalysts with precise nano structural control, due to their unique ability to bridge molecular design and functional performance. Polymers offer several advantages as precursors for carbon materials. (1) Wide availability and resource utilization: Polymers such as polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polyethylene (PE), and polyamide (PA) are abundant in everyday life [ 136 ]. Their use as carbon precursors not only addresses environmental pollution from polymer waste but also facilitates resource recovery from discarded plastics. (2) Defined Structure: Polymers possess well-defined structures, enabling precise control over the composition and molecular architecture of carbon catalysts. This allows for specific functionalization. Extensive research on polymer carbonization mechanisms has provided insights into their structural evolution during pyrolysis, aiding in the design of functionalized carbon catalysts [ 55 ]. (3) Controllable Structure: With well-established polymer synthesis and processing technologies, polymer nanostructures can be tailored into zero- to three-dimensional forms across a wide size range, from a few nanometers to hundreds of nanometers. This versatility supports the design and fabrication of carbon catalysts with precise structural features [ 92,143,144 ]. (4) Controllable Active Sites: Polymers like polyacrylonitrile, polyaniline, and polythiophene contain heteroatoms (e.g., N and S), which can be uniformly incorporated into the carbon matrix during carbonization. This enables targeted heteroatom doping, creating well-defined active sites that significantly enhance catalyst functionality [ 145,146 ]. In recent years, the use of well-defined polymers as precursors for synthesizing carbon-based nonmetallic catalysts with precise structures has garnered significant attention. Polyacrylonitrile (PAN), the primary precursor for industrial carbon fiber production, is particularly appealing for preparing carbon catalysts due to its low cost and broad commercial availability [ 147 ]. During carbonization, the cyclization of adjacent cyano groups along PAN polymer chains, followed by dehydrogenation, enables the targeted synthesis of pyridinic nitrogen species. Qiao et al. [ 62 ] developed an innovative approach to synthesizing pyridinic N-rich aromatic ladder-structured materials by controlling the self-assembly of PAN polymer chains (Figs. 15(a) , (b)). The resulting material demonstrated excellent catalytic performance, achieving ∼93% acetylene conversion with >99% selectivity for vinyl chloride and maintaining stability over 200 h of testing. The catalyst’s activity is attributed to three types of pyridinic N active sites within the ladder structure (Fig. 15(c)). Notably, pyridinic N sites with a neighboring hydrogen atom exhibit higher activity, as the H atom stabilizes the transition state through H–Cl bonding, thereby lowering the energy barrier. Energy barriers for these sites were calculated to be 29.8 and 47.4 kcal mol–1, significantly lower than the 83.2 and 84.4 kcal mol–1 for sites lacking a neighboring H atom [ 62 ]. It is worth noting that even when the same polymer is used as a precursor, the catalytic performance of the resulting catalysts can vary significantly depending on the synthesis method employed. Chen et al. [ 56 ] introduced a novel ultrasonic chemistry method to synthesize NC sphere catalysts derived from aminophenol/formaldehyde resin spheres (APFS) (Fig. 15(d)). This green, template-free, and organic solvent-free approach uses ultrasonic chemistry to initiate resin crosslinking reactions between aminophenol and formaldehyde through free radicals, enabling the ultra-rapid formation of NC spheres (U-NC) with remarkably high pyrrolic nitrogen content in just 5 min. Compared to conventional methods, the ultrasonic chemistry process promotes free radical formation, accelerating the ring-opening, addition, and condensation reactions between aminophenol and formaldehyde. The instantaneous high temperature and pressure generated by ultrasound further facilitate the incorporation of nitrogen species into the material. After calcination of APFS, the resulting NC catalyst, enriched with pyrrolic nitrogen, demonstrated superior catalytic activity and stability in acetylene hydrochlorination (Figs. 15(e)–(k)). The U-NC catalyst achieved an impressive space-time-yield (1.6 gvcm gcat –1 h–1), comparable to reported metallic catalysts. A linear relationship was observed between pyrrolic nitrogen content and C2H2 conversion, indicating that pyrrolic N significantly enhances acetylene hydrochlorination performance by effectively mediating HCl adsorption. This study highlights the potential of ultrasonic chemistry in fabricating advanced carbon catalysts with excellent catalytic properties. Additionally, researchers have synthesized a variety of carbon catalysts from different polymer precursors and evaluated their performance in acetylene hydrochlorination. Liu et al. [ 109 ] developed a nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts using a melamine/formaldehyde/polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) coating-pyrolysis method. Among these, the optimized N@CBC-FE catalyst demonstrated an acetylene conversion rate of 75% at 220 °C with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 50 h–1, maintaining stable performance over 120 h of operation. The exceptional performance of the N@CBC-FE catalyst was primarily attributed to a unique nitrogen intercalation pathway formed by the polymeric network coating, which resulted from the interactions among formaldehyde, PVA, and melamine. Additionally, the abundant mesopores in N@CBC-FE facilitated efficient reactant transport and mitigated catalyst deactivation, contributing to its longevity and stability. Qiao et al. [ 37 ] developed a green poly(o-phenylenediamine) framework as a novel catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. This material, composed of a phenazine backbone enriched with well-defined pyridinic nitrogen species, served as an ideal model for investigating the catalytic role of pyridinic N. The polymer exhibited bifunctional properties, achieving approximately 95% acetylene conversion at 280 °C and demonstrating remarkable stability during a continuous 100-h test. Notably, the polymer-derived carbon catalyst exhibited activity comparable to that of a traditional 6wt% Hg/C catalyst, highlighting its potential as a sustainable alternative [ 37 ]. The primary goal of preparing NC materials is to leverage pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen species for the adsorption and activation of reactants. However, achieving high catalytic activity requires precise control over both the nitrogen content within the carbon framework and the chemical state of the nitrogen atoms, which remains a significant challenge during synthesis. Li et al. [ 106 ] addressed this challenge by synthesizing multi-porous NC materials with abundant defect sites using silica sol as a template and phenol, melamine, and formaldehyde as carbon and nitrogen precursors. The resultant melamine-phenol-formaldehyde (MPF) resin, enriched with pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen species, produced NC materials featuring a hierarchical pore structure and localized active sites. These defect sites, characterized by high electronegativity, coupled with synergistic interactions between pyridinic nitrogen and π-functional groups (e.g., C=C bonds and triazine rings), were instrumental in activating HCl and C2H2 molecules. Among the synthesized catalysts, MPF-800, with the highest pyridinic nitrogen content, demonstrated superior adsorption and activation of reactants, leading to significantly enhanced catalytic performance. This study highlights the importance of optimizing both the nitrogen species and the structural properties of N-doped carbon materials to achieve efficient and sustainable catalysis in acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.1.2.5 Nitrogen-containing compounds derived from N-doped carbon materials Nitrogen-containing compounds are essential precursors for synthesizing NC materials, which have garnered significant attention as sustainable and efficient catalysts in various reactions, including acetylene hydrochlorination. Unlike other methods, this approach allows precise control over the nitrogen doping levels by adjusting the number of nitrogen-containing precursors used. Wei et al. [ 26 ] proposed a novel strategy for preparing sustainable nanoporous carbon (NPC) catalysts with high catalytic performance for acetylene hydrochlorination, utilizing waste PVC as a carbon source in combination with melamine via a solid grinding method (Fig. 16(a) ). By tuning the amount of melamine, both the nitrogen content and the defect sites in the NPCs can be easily adjusted (Figs. 16(b), (c)). Furthermore, these NPCs exhibit excellent catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination, and the generated VCM can be polymerized to produce PVC, thus enabling material recycling. Lu et al. [ 113 ] developed macroporous carbon catalysts with high nitrogen content by using melamine as the nitrogen precursor for in-situ doping. The CN-2 catalyst achieved a nitrogen content of 9.74%, with a pore size of 300 nm and strong adsorption capacities for both C2H2 and HCl. As nitrogen content increases, the pore size and surface area also increase, along with an increase in defect density, which correlates with enhanced catalytic activity. Liu et al. [ 109 ] employed a hydrothermal synthesis method to produce nitrogen-doped porous carbon (NPC) catalysts. These NC catalysts exhibited distinct morphologies and excellent thermal stability, making them highly effective for acetylene hydrochlorination. In addition, NC catalysts with tunable pore structures can be synthesized by incorporating different pore-forming agents during the preparation process. Kaiser et al. [ 148 ] developed a salt-template-assisted synthesis strategy combined with chemical blowing to control the textural properties of N-doped carbons (NCs). This method employed NH4Cl as a blowing agent, hexamethylene tetraamine (HMT) as the carbon/nitrogen precursor, and Mg(OAc)2 or CaCO3 as thermally decomposable templates (Figs. 16(d)–(f)). The simultaneous increase in both micro- and mesopore volumes is attributed to enhanced gas evolution through the reaction of the salt template and the chemical blowing agent. Additionally, the in-situ formation of metal oxides and chlorides (e.g., MgO/MgCl2 and CaO/CaCl2) further acts as templates, promoting the generation of additional meso- and macropores. While micropores can become blocked during acetylene hydrochlorination, meso- and macropores are structurally stable, significantly improving the catalyst’s lifetime. The hierarchical NCs demonstrated approximately 50 times longer stability compared to their non-templated counterparts, rivaling the performance of benchmark metal-based catalysts. 3.2 Synthetic strategies for carbon defect carbon catalysts Defects in carbon catalysts can generally be categorized into two typical configurations. (1). Reconstructed topological or vacancy defects, which include defects such as pentagons (C5), heptagons (C7), octagons (C8), and mono-/divacancies. These topological defects are often part of more complex defect patterns involving non-hexagonal rings, such as pentagon-octagon-pentagon (C5-8-5), pentagon-heptagon- heptagon-pentagon (C5-7-7-5), or pentagon-heptagon-pentagon- heptagon (C5-7-5-7), among others. (2). Heteroatom modification, where metal or nonmetal atoms are incorporated into these defects, forming various coordinating structures that alter the electronic properties of the defects and enhance their catalytic performance [ 79 ]. The diversity of intrinsic carbon defects in DC materials presents a significant challenge in precisely targeting the synthesis of specific types and densities of defects. Due to the absence of well-established design strategies and synthetic methods, current approaches for defect tailoring largely rely on trial and error. The advancement of traditional synthesis methods is essential for achieving precise control over defect sites in carbon catalysts. Various approaches, including in situ doping and modification strategies, have been explored to synthesize carbon catalysts with tailored defect structures [ 82,149 ]. In addition, techniques such as plasma and electron beam etching are effective for generating vacancy and edge defects, while carbothermal reduction (removal of heteroatoms from carbon materials) is suitable for introducing topological defects [ 80 ]. 3.2.1 Fabricating carbon defect by removing heteroatoms containing groups The removal of heteroatoms via thermal treatment is a widely employed method for generating intrinsic DC materials, enabling the large-scale production of defect structures under controlled conditions (e.g., temperature and atmosphere). During carbonization, the loss of nitrogen atoms can induce the formation of single-atom vacancies. Due to the instability of these vacancies, they often combine to form divacancies, which typically consist of one octagon and two pentagons. This configuration is commonly referred to as a G585 defect, a topological defect formed by the fusion of two pentagons and one octagon [ 22 ]. The degree of defect formation can be controlled by adjusting the heat treatment temperature and the amount of heteroatom introduced. Yao et al. [ 83,150,151 ] were among the first to apply this strategy to regulate defect content in carbon materials. Using a nitrogen-rich porous organic framework (PAF-40) as a precursor, they synthesized carbon catalysts with vacancy defects via high-temperature nitrogen removal (Fig. 17(a) ). DFT calculations revealed that the catalytic performance at the G585 defect site on graphene exceeds that of nitrogen-doped sites. Experimental results further confirmed that the defect content in NC catalysts can be significantly enhanced by high-temperature nitrogen removal, offering a versatile approach to optimize catalytic properties [ 83 ]. Building on this strategy, the researchers developed a series of defect-rich carbon catalysts for VCM production. Dai et al. [ 22 ] controlled the formation of carbon defects during the synthesis of NCs by removing nitrogen atoms at high temperatures. Elevated temperatures facilitated nitrogen loss, leading to an increased density of carbon defects in the resulting catalysts. The catalytic performance of the NC catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination improved with the increase in carbon defect density. It was proposed that the carbon defects in the catalysts influence the adsorption of C2H2 and HCl, thereby enhancing their conversion [ 22 ]. Defect sites and nitrogen species in carbon materials play a pivotal role in determining their catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination. However, a trade-off often exists between increasing defect site density and preserving nitrogen content. Typically, elevating the calcination temperature to enhance defect density leads to a reduction in nitrogen species. Therefore, designing catalysts with abundant inherent defect sites while retaining nitrogen content is critical for optimizing catalytic activity. Zhu et al. [ 45 ] developed defect-rich high-nitrogen carbon materials that exhibited excellent catalytic performance and stability in acetylene hydrochlorination. As the carbonization temperature increased, nitrogen content decreased, while defect site density initially increased and then decreased. Correspondingly, the acetylene conversion rate followed a similar trend, rising initially and then declining with higher temperatures. NC-800, with its high defect density and optimal nitrogen content, achieved the best catalytic performance and stability. The carbon-nitrogen material demonstrated outstanding catalytic activity and stability when both carbon defects and nitrogen content were carefully optimized [ 45 ]. Guo et al. [ 101 ] synthesized nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon materials (NPCs-T) through a self-assembly method, which exhibited more defect sites than traditional spherical carbon materials. The synergistic interaction between defect sites and optimal nitrogen species enhanced the adsorption and activation of acetylene and hydrogen chloride, thereby promoting the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. At high temperatures, typically ranging from 400 to 1000 °C, oxygen-containing functional groups on carbon materials (e.g., graphite, graphene, carbon nanotubes, and activated carbon) undergo thermal decomposition, often via redox reactions with carbon or reducing agents in the atmosphere. During this process, oxygen atoms from the functional groups combine with carbon or are released as volatile gases such as CO, CO2, or H2O, thereby removing oxygen and generating vacancies or defects in the carbon structure. The density of surface defects can be further enhanced either by directly removing surface oxygen groups or by employing a two-step process: oxidation through a solid-phase nitrate oxidative method followed by thermal treatment. This approach is cost-effective and scalable, utilizing inexpensive and earth-abundant raw materials in a standard activated carbon production process, making it a promising method for metal-free catalysis. Our group developed defect-rich activated carbon catalysts using a nitrate-assisted strategy. This method enhanced the surface defect density through either direct removal of surface oxygen groups or a solid-phase nitrate oxidation process followed by thermal treatment (Figs. 17(e), (f)) [ 24 ]. The modified activated carbon showed significant improvements in acetylene hydrochlorination performance, with the acetylene conversion rate increasing from 20% to 61.6%. Further analysis revealed a linear correlation between the catalytic performance of activated carbons and the density of surface defects. Theoretical studies confirmed that surface defect sites act as active centers for acetylene hydrochlorination. Similarly, our group synthesized a nanodiamond-graphene composite material (ND@G) with a nanodiamond (ND) core and a defective graphitic shell by annealing ND at 900 °C under an argon atmosphere. The defective ND@G exhibited exceptional catalytic activity in acetylene hydrochlorination, achieving an acetylene conversion of 50%, a vinyl chloride selectivity of up to 99.5% at 220 °C, and a C2H2 gas hourly space velocity of 300 h–1, comparable to that of a 0.25% Au/C catalyst [ 23 ]. 3.2.2 Fabricating carbon defect through etching Traditional approaches for regulating the defect structures of carbon catalysts often result in the unintended introduction of non-target defect types. Therefore, the development of new strategies to selectively generate specific defect species in carbon catalysts is of critical importance. Jia et al. [ 80 ] successfully synthesized highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (D-HOPG) enriched with five-membered ring carbon defects using a plasma extraction etching method. The preparation process, depicted in Figs. 18(a) –(d), involves initial argon plasma etching to produce argon-etched highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (Ar-HOPG). This is followed by acid treatment and subsequent carbonization in an ammonia atmosphere, which introduces pyridinium nitrogen species (Pr-N) at the edges of nitrogen-doped HOPG. Finally, a “one-to-one” pyrolysis reconstruction process during annealing converts these structures into a D-HOPG catalyst rich in five-membered ring carbon defects. Experimental and theoretical analyses identified these five-membered ring defects as the primary active sites for the acidic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), demonstrating superior catalytic activity compared to nitrogen-doped sites. Similarly, Yao et al. [ 82 ] synthesized a class of DC materials by transforming nitrogen-doping sites into specific defect structures through “edge engineering.” Both experimental and theoretical studies revealed that targeted defect structures could be selectively created by eliminating specific nitrogen-doping sites. For instance, the removal of graphite nitrogen results in the formation of a C585 defect structure, pyridine nitrogen corresponds to an S-C5 defect structure, and pyrrole nitrogen leads to an A-C5 defect structure. Although the methods discussed above enable precise regulation of carbon defect structures, the overall catalytic performance of DCs still lags behind that of metal catalysts, primarily due to the insufficient density of catalytically active defect sites in the prepared carbon materials. Yao et al. [ 152 ] addressed this limitation by demonstrating that the controlled synthesis of carbon catalysts with high defect density can be achieved through an interfacial self-corrosion strategy. Their study revealed that the removal and rearrangement of carbon atoms could be precisely controlled via an in-situ carbothermal reduction reaction between ZnO quantum dots and carbon atoms confined within a carbon cavity. This process generated numerous defect sites by creating a carbon nanocavity structure that restricted CO2 diffusion and facilitated CO generation (CO2 + C → 2CO). The higher C/O ratio of CO compared to CO2 promoted more extensive decarbonization, thereby increasing the defect density in the reconstructed carbon framework (Figs. 18(e)–(k)). The resulting high-defect-density carbon catalysts exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in both alkaline and acidic electrolytes, underscoring their versatility and effectiveness. Furthermore, Yao et al. [ 153 ] employed two innovative nonmetallic thiophene-sulfur covalent organic frameworks (FMS-CoFS) as model catalysts to further explore the catalytic mechanisms of DC materials. Experimental results showed that FMS-CoFS demonstrated significantly higher catalytic activity than thiophene-free covalent organic frameworks (COFs). Notably, the catalytic performance of the COFs increased with the number of thiophene-sulfur groups, confirming that the five-membered ring structure of the thiophene-sulfur group served as the true active center. This organic synthesis-assisted strategy offers a promising pathway for the precise design and construction of complex defect structures in carbon materials, providing a foundation for advancing the catalytic performance of DCs to levels comparable with, or surpassing, those of metal catalysts. 4 Mechanism of acetylene hydrochlorination on carbon surface 4.1 Reaction mechanism via DFT method The acetylene hydrochlorination reaction fundamentally involves the synergistic adsorption and interaction of acetylene (C2H2) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) at the active sites on the catalyst surface. However, understanding their unique reaction pathways and underlying mechanisms remains a critical area of ongoing investigation. In the context of carbon-based nonmetallic catalysts, acetylene hydrochlorination primarily proceeds via two mechanisms: the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism and the Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism [ 53,154 ]. The key distinction between these mechanisms lies in the adsorption modes and interaction processes of the reactant molecules on the catalyst surface. The Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism represents a key pathway in acetylene hydrochlorination, characterized by the direct reaction of a gas-phase reactant with a species adsorbed on the catalyst surface. This mechanism is typically observed under conditions of high temperature, low reactant concentration, or when reactions occur at isolated active sites. In this process, acetylene (C2H2) is first adsorbed onto active sites on the catalyst surface, while gaseous HCl directly interacts with the adsorbed C2H2 to form intermediates, ultimately yielding vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) (Fig. 19(a) ). Li et al. [ 53 ] utilized NC nanotubes as a model system to investigate the binding energies of C2H2 and HCl at various active sites. Their calculations revealed that the binding energies of C2H2 at nitrogen-doped sites were consistently higher than those of HCl, confirming that acetylene adsorption is the initial step in the ER mechanism. Following this adsorption, gaseous HCl reacts with surface-bound acetylene, with the rate-determining step being the activation of HCl, which facilitates the formation and desorption of vinyl chloride. Nitrogen doping plays a critical role by enhancing the nucleophilicity of the carbon nanotubes, promoting stronger interactions between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of NCNTs and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of C2H2. This interaction significantly increases the adsorption capacity for C2H2, improving catalytic efficiency compared to undoped catalysts. Additionally, studies suggest that electron transfer from nitrogen-doped catalysts to HCl during adsorption is pivotal. This electron transfer increases the electron density at nitrogen sites, enhancing HCl adsorption. Consequently, in nitrogen-doped systems, the initial reaction step involves HCl adsorption at nitrogen sites, underscoring the importance of electronic properties in governing catalytic performance. Li et al. [ 62 ] investigated the preferential adsorption behavior of acetylene (C2H2) and hydrogen chloride (HCl) on polyacrylonitrile-derived carbon catalysts. Their findings demonstrated that catalysts pre-adsorbed with HCl produced significantly more vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) compared to those pre-adsorbed with acetylene, indicating a preferential adsorption of HCl. This observation suggests that HCl adsorption is likely the initial step in the acetylene hydrochlorination process on polyacrylonitrile-derived carbon catalysts (Fig. 19(b)). A key advantage of the Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism is its efficient utilization of active sites due to low surface coverage. In this mechanism, only one reactant, typically C2H2 is adsorbed on the catalyst surface, while the other reactant, HCl, directly participates in the reaction from the gas phase. This ensures a higher availability of active sites for the reaction. Furthermore, the ER mechanism exhibits notable resilience against catalyst deactivation. Even when some active sites are blocked by carbon deposits or strongly adsorbed HCl, the reaction can still proceed at the remaining active sites, thereby extending the operational lifespan of the catalyst. These attributes highlight the practical advantages of the ER mechanism in industrial acetylene hydrochlorination processes. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism is a key pathway in acetylene hydrochlorination, characterized by the simultaneous adsorption of both reactants, acetylene (C2H2) and hydrogen chloride (HCl), onto the catalyst surface, where they react either through surface migration or direct interaction (Fig. 19(c)). This mechanism requires the catalyst’s active sites to possess strong adsorption capacities for both reactants. However, excessive adsorption strength can result in active site blockage by reactants or byproducts, ultimately compromising the catalyst’s long-term stability. Dai et al. [ 16 ] investigated the acetylene hydrochlorination mechanism on g-C3N4/AC catalysts and concluded that the reaction follows the LH mechanism. Their study revealed that HCl adsorbs onto g-C₃N₄ through an interaction between the H(1) atom of HCl and the N(1) atom of g-C3N4, while acetylene adsorbs via the π-bond interaction between C2H2 and the C(1) atom of g- C3N4. Notably, under practical conditions, the LH and Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanisms can coexist, with the dominant pathway depending on reaction conditions and catalyst properties. Li et al. [ 130 ] further explored the dynamic reaction pathways of NC catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. They observed that the reaction often initiates via the LH mechanism, with pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen atoms acting as dual active sites. However, pyridinic nitrogen is more susceptible to deactivation due to the strong adsorption of HCl, which leads to a transition toward the ER mechanism, where pyrrolic nitrogen becomes the sole active site (Fig. 19(d)). This dynamic shift underscores the intricate interplay between reaction pathways and catalyst properties, highlighting the need to optimize active site characteristics to achieve stable and efficient catalytic performance. 4.2 Design basis of carbon catalysts via DFT method Extensive research on heteroatom doping has demonstrated that different heteroatoms play distinct roles in the acetylene hydrochlorination process [ 39 ]. Both theoretical and experimental studies indicate that carbon atoms bonded to nitrogen serve as active sites in N-doped carbon catalysts, with nitrogen doping significantly enhancing C2H2 adsorption compared to undoped carbon [ 63 ]. This enhancement arises from the increased nucleophilicity of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) after nitrogen doping, which strengthens the interaction between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of N-doped CNTs and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of C2H2, thereby improving catalytic performance [ 17 ]. Notably, boron and nitrogen doping exhibit contrasting effects on charge transfer between adsorbed C2H2 and the catalyst. Pyridinic nitrogen, in particular, generates adjacent carbon atoms with a high affinity for C2H2 adsorption, especially in the presence of sulfide groups. This synergy between pyridinic nitrogen and sulfur doping significantly enhances C2H2 adsorption, promoting the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction [ 53 ]. carbon catalysts co-doped with sulfur and nitrogen demonstrate a marked improvement in C2H2 adsorption capacity, emphasizing the critical role of heteroatom synergy in catalysis. For optimal catalytic performance, a delicate balance between C2H2 adsorption and HCl activation is essential. Excessive C2H2 binding strength can impede subsequent reaction steps by creating a substantial energy barrier, ultimately reducing overall catalytic efficiency. Striking this balance is crucial to achieving efficient and sustainable catalytic activity in acetylene hydrochlorination [ 53 ]. The defect chemistry of carbon nanostructures has long been a focal point of research due to its profound influence on electronic properties and surface reactivity. High-energy sites and catalytic centers are predominantly located at the edges of sp 2 carbon nanostructures. These edges, often terminated with hydrogen or other heteroatoms, exhibit enhanced reactivity due to the presence of unsaturated bonds. Intrinsic defects sometimes referred to as “auto-doping,” arise from structural irregularities in sp 2 carbon frameworks, introducing slight perturbations to electron-hole symmetry. These defects improve adsorption properties and facilitate catalytic reactions, enabling DC materials to demonstrate remarkable stability and performance as metal-free catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. In a landmark study, Sajjad Ali [ 155 ] employed DFT calculations to investigate the reaction mechanisms of DC catalysts. This study identified a range of defect configurations including monovacancies, divacancies, and Stone-Wales defects—on single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) as active sites for acetylene hydrochlorination. These defect sites exhibited significantly enhanced catalytic activity compared to pristine SWCNTs (Fig. 19(c)), with each defect configuration possessing distinct electronic structures. Notably, monovacancy defects displayed a higher density of states near the Fermi level, contributing to their superior activity. Adsorption studies revealed that acetylene (C2H2) exhibited stronger adsorption than hydrogen chloride (HCl) on these defective sites, indicating that C2H2 adsorption likely initiates the reaction. Moreover, defective graphene variants, including monovacancy graphene (MVG), divacancy graphene (DVG), and Stone-Wales defective graphene (SWDG), demonstrated narrower HOMO-LUMO gaps compared to pristine graphene (PG). This narrowing enhanced their adsorption capacities for both C2H2 and HCl. The adsorption energy trends for C2H2 and HCl followed the order: DVG > MVG > SWDG > PG. Among these, MVG and DVG exhibited stronger adsorption for C2H2 relative to HCl, while SWDG favored HCl adsorption. The acetylene hydrochlorination reaction proceeds through five primary steps: (A) adsorption of C2H2, (B) interaction of HCl with adsorbed C2H2, (C) activation of HCl, (D) formation of vinyl chloride, and (E) desorption of the product (Fig. 19(d)). These findings underscore the critical importance of tailoring defect structures on carbon surfaces to optimize their catalytic properties. Rational control over defect configurations is essential for designing efficient carbon-based, metal-free catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. This study establishes a robust framework for utilizing DC materials as sustainable and high-performance catalysts, offering significant potential for advancing metal-free catalytic technologies and enabling greener, more efficient industrial processes. 4.3 Deactivation mechanism and stabilization strategy Thanks to the development of heteroatom doping and defect engineering strategies, various carbon catalysts have been developed for VCM production, including nitrogen-doped carbon, boron-doped carbon, and defect-rich carbon. However, their stability remains markedly inferior to that of metal-based counterparts, with the deactivation of NC catalysts posing a particularly persistent challenge. NC catalysts exhibit a well-recognized trade-off: while they deliver high catalytic activity, their stability under reaction conditions is inadequate [ 5 ]. For instance, De et al. [ 56 ] synthesized a NC catalyst (U-NC-550) using amino-phenolic resin as a precursor. Under testing conditions of 200 °C and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 40 h–1 for 50 h, the acetylene conversion rate declined from 84% to 65%. Similarly, Zhu et al. [ 102 ] developed the Chi800 catalyst from a chitosan precursor, which exhibited a steep decrease in acetylene conversion efficiency from 91% to 31% after 60 hours of testing at 220 °C and 36 h–1. These examples highlight the formidable challenge of improving the stability of nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts, a critical barrier hindering their widespread industrial application. To address this challenge, Perez-Ramirez et al. [ 148 ] proposed a salt-template-assisted synthesis strategy combined with a chemical bubbling method to optimize the pore architecture of NC catalysts. Their findings revealed that catalysts with layered pore structures exhibit superior stability compared to those with microporous or non-porous architectures. However, while increasing the specific surface area and tailoring pore structures can mitigate catalyst deactivation to some extent, these approaches fail to eliminate deactivation, particularly under conditions where pore blockage occurs. The carbonaceous deposits observed on NC catalysts are primarily attributed to the polymerization of acetylene or vinyl chloride molecules. A more effective solution lies in designing active sites with finely tuned electronic structures to suppress such polymerization. This electronic structure-driven design strategy is a promising avenue for enhancing the stability and durability of nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts, paving the way for their broader implementation in acetylene hydrochlorination and other industrial applications [ 57 ]. To address the issue of catalytic stability, the group developed a highly stable boron-nitrogen co-doped mesoporous carbon (B, N-MC) catalyst using polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as the carbon and nitrogen source and boric acid as the boron source. By varying the boric acid concentration, the electronic structure of the catalyst was fine-tuned to investigate the influence of boron doping on the activity and stability of nitrogen-doped catalysts [ 57 ]. Experimental results demonstrated a substantial improvement in the stability of the PAN-derived carbon catalyst following boric acid modification. Notably, the catalyst exhibited no observable deactivation even after a 500-h lifespan test (Fig. 20(a) ). Post-reaction Ar-TPD analysis identified C6H6 signal peaks, attributed to acetylene self-polymerization products (Fig. 20(b)). The C6H6 signal intensity for the B, N-MC(0.5)-used catalyst was significantly lower than that for the N-MC-used catalyst, indicating that boric acid modification effectively enhanced the resistance to C2H2 self-polymerization. This enhancement was further corroborated by C2H2-TPSR characterization, which revealed a marked improvement in the catalyst’s resistance to acetylene self-polymerization upon boric acid modification (Figs. 20(c), (d)). Additionally, theoretical calculations provided insights into the underlying mechanism of acetylene self-polymerization suppression. The introduction of B-N species into the nitrogen-doped catalyst was shown to substantially increase the energy barrier for acetylene self-polymerization, thereby contributing to the observed stability enhancement (Figs. 20(e), (f)). These findings underscore the pivotal role of boron modification in mitigating deactivation and extending the operational lifespan of NC catalysts, paving the way for their broader application in industrial catalysis. Although the stability of carbon catalysts has significantly improved with the support of pore and electronic engineering strategies, their durability still does not match that of traditional metal catalysts. Therefore, to further enhance the service life of carbon catalysts, attention must be given to potential regeneration methods. Li et al. [ 5 ] employed dopamine to prepare a polydopamine (PDA)/SiC nanocomposite by wrapping a layer of PDA material around the SiC substrate, using it as a metal-free carbon catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. During the reaction, the conversion began to decline after the initial 350 hours, decreasing by 13% after 1000 h, as shown in Fig. 20(g). Furthermore, it is proposed that both acetylene and vinyl chloride may have oligomerized and covered the active sites, leading to catalyst deactivation. Moreover, the authors observed that catalytic performance was restored, and carbon deposits were removed by NH3 treatment, as shown in Fig. 20(h). The signal corresponding to HCN increases above 500 °C, while the NH3 signal decays above 650 °C. This is likely the result of a reaction between the carbon-like deposits and NH3. In this way, the carbon-like deposits are removed, and the catalyst activity is restored [ 5 ]. Lu et al. [ 100 ] propose an alternative regeneration method using ZnCl2, as they believe the NH3 method cannot fully remove coke deposits and also reduces the surface area. As shown in Fig. 20(i), the catalytic performance is restored after ZnCl2 treatment. Surprisingly, the surface area of the catalyst dramatically increased from 14.24 to 507.55 m2 g–1 after regeneration. In most cases, the durability of metal-free doped carbon catalysts is around 300 h, which is significantly lower than that of conventional mercury-based catalysts, which exhibit stable performance for over 10000 h. Therefore, it is urgent to find new methods to enhance the durability of carbon catalysts. 5 Summary and outlook Carbon-based metal-free catalysts have garnered significant attention as a promising sustainable alternative to toxic and environmentally hazardous mercury-based systems in the coal-based PVC industry. Over the past decade, the catalytic performance of carbon catalysts has improved remarkably, even surpassing that of metal catalysts, demonstrating great potential for industrialization. This review summarizes recent advances in carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination, from heteroatom doping to intrinsic carbon defects, and provides various synthetic strategies for these catalysts. The current understanding of carbon catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination is also extracted, including the identity and quantity of active sites, structure-activity relationships, reaction mechanisms, and stabilization strategies. However, these reports have been limited to laboratory-scale research. Transitioning from laboratory research to scalable commercialization in metal-free carbon catalysis, especially in the context of acetylene hydrochlorination and broader heterogeneous carbon catalysts, involves several key challenges and strategic considerations. Carbon-based metal-free catalysts face several challenges that need to be addressed to achieve industrial viability and replace traditional metal catalysts. Firstly, catalyst stability and durability are critical issues. The lifespan of carbon-based non-metallic catalysts requires further improvement. Most reported lifetimes are still below 2000 h, and achieving stable performance beyond this threshold remains a critical challenge. Currently, the primary cause of deactivation in metal-free carbon catalysts is attributed to carbon deposition, which leads to pore blockage. Despite this understanding, research on the specific carbon-depositing species, the active centers responsible for carbon deposition, and the detailed reaction pathways remain insufficient. Secondly, the scalability of synthesis poses a major challenge. Laboratory-scale methods for producing carbon catalysts, such as chemical vapor deposition and pyrolysis, may not be cost-effective or reproducible at industrial scales. Uniformly controlling defects, dopant distribution (e.g., nitrogen, boron, sulfur), and porosity in bulk production is also difficult. In addition to performance, environmental impacts during manufacturing and handling of spent catalysts must be considered. A comprehensive life cycle assessment of metal-free carbon catalysts is needed to evaluate their sustainability. Recycling deactivated catalysts could reduce costs, minimize pollution, and conserve resources. Therefore, developing low-cost and sustainable regeneration methods for these catalysts should be prioritized to advance their industrialization for acetylene hydrochlorination. Furthermore, for practical engineering applications, carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination must be shaped into specific forms due to the fixed bed reactors to ensure effective multiphase interface contact, minimize pressure drops, eliminate bed inhomogeneity, and enhance mass transfer of reactants and products. The shaped process of carbon materials always leads to loss of performance, In the further, the shaped carbon catalysts with enough mechanical stability are essential for commercialization. Thirdly, active site identification is less straightforward for carbon catalysts compared to metal catalysts. The active sites in carbocatalysts, such as graphitic nitrogen, edge defects, and oxygen functionalities, are less well-understood, complicating rational design. This lack of mechanistic clarity hinders optimization for specific reactions like acetylene hydrochlorination. Fourthly, economic viability is crucial for competing with established metal catalysts. Using premium carbon precursors, such as graphene, carbon dot, or nano diamond may increase costs. Sustainable sourcing of carbon, such as biomass-derived carbons and waste polymers, could reduce costs and align with green chemistry principles. Lastly, performance under real conditions must be validated. Industrial feedstocks often contain impurities, and lab tests using pure reagents may not reflect real-world performance. Achieving high space-time yields and selectivity comparable to metal catalysts, such as the >99% selectivity of HgCl₂ in acetylene hydrochlorination, is essential for industrial adoption. In summary, future research should prioritize the identification of suitable shaping techniques, the optimization of catalyst structure and mechanical stability, and the enhancement of catalytic activity and durability. Achieving these goals will enable the production of metal-free carbon catalysts capable of delivering long-term, efficient performance in industrial acetylene hydrochlorination processes, thereby making them a practical and sustainable alternative to metal-based catalysts. To advance the industrialization of carbon catalysts, collaborative efforts between researchers, engineers, and industry leaders will be essential. Focused research on optimizing each of these bottleneck areas, could lead to breakthroughs that enable more sustainable and cost-effective large-scale production. As industries move toward more sustainable practices, the continued development of high-performance carbon catalysts could play a key role in achieving those goals. Encouraging further work in these areas will not only improve the industrialization of acetylene hydrochlorination but also open doors for similar advancements in other chemical processes that rely on catalysis. Guojun Lan (Institute of Industrial catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology) received his B. Sc., and PhD degree from Zhejiang University of Technology in 2010 and 2016, respectively. During the period from January 2013 to August 2015, he was jointly trained at State key laboratory of Catalysis (SKLC), in Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (DICP), the Chinese Academy of Sciences. He carried out postdoctoral research in the College of Environment, at Zhejiang University of Technology from 2016 to 2018. Since 2019, he has been working at the Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology. His research interests mainly focus on the development of porous carbon materials and industrial catalysts, mainly include the design, synthesis and catalytic application of carbon-based catalysts, catalytic synthesis of vinyl chloride, green ammonia synthesis and hydrogenation of biomass derived chemicals in aqueous phase. He has coauthored more than 50 peer-reviewed papers. Ying Li (Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology). Prof. Li Ying received his B.S. degree from Shandong Normal University (P. R. China) in 1998, and Ph.D. degree from Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2005. She carried out postdoctoral research at Institute of Catalysis, Eindhoven University of Technology (Netherlands) from 2005 to 2007. Since the end of 2007, she has been working in Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology. Her research interests mainly focus on: carbon catalysis, preparation and application of porous carbon, green ammonia synthesis, and carbon-based solid waste resource utilization. She has published more than 200 peer-reviewed papers and 80 patents.

coredata.dc:description: The development of metal-free carbon catalysts has garnered significant attention as a promising approach to address the challenges of sustainable catalysis, particularly in the replacement of toxic and environmentally hazardous mercury-based systems for the coal-based PVC industry. Within a decade of development, the catalytic performance of carbon catalysts has been improved greatly and even shows superiorities over metal catalysts in some cases, which have demonstrated great potential as sustainable alternatives to mercury catalysts. This review provides a comprehensive summary of the recent advancements in carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. It encompasses a wide range of aspects, including the identification of active sites from heteroatom doping to intrinsic carbon defects, the various synthetic strategies employed, the reaction and deactivation mechanisms of carbon catalysts, and the current insights into the key challenges that are encountered on the journey from laboratory research to scalable commercialization within the field of carbon catalysts. The review offers foundational insights and practical guidelines for designing green carbon catalysts systems, not only for acetylene hydrochlorination but also for other heterogeneous catalytic reactions.
